Correcting for inaccurate submission:  53.8% +/- 1% for Remain, 70% certain. 20% possibility that it will be lower but still with a victory for Remain. Polls, esp. online polls, tend to underestimate the conservative vote and the status quo bias. Those same polls also tend to have an unrepresentative sample where turnout--based on various models--is expected to be much higher than in the general population. YouGov at least may have tried to change their panels a little to adjust for that discrepancy but they've used data from general elections to do so which I believe means they're not sufficiently well-calibrated for this referendum. People who are undecided, or say that they don't know how they'll vote, are more likely to vote for the conservative option and/or the status quo, provided they show up at all. These surveys tend to contain a disproportionately high number of responses from politically interested people with strong opinions. The first should indicate a victory for Remain based on the averages of the most recent polls that put the two camps neck and neck, further supported by tendency for most phone polls to show Remain ahead.  One possible problem for remain would be the "lazy Labour" problem with young Labour voters who're more likely to be pro-EU being less likely to turn up to vote. I think however that that problem is a consequence of the British electoral system and that a referendum should see a much higher turnout in that group. I believe that overall turnout will be fairly high for the referendum. The previous EU referendum in the UK had a turnout about 5% lower than in the preceding general election in spite of a politically interested electorate. However, I believe several things speak in favour of a higher turnout for this referendum: simple majority, perception of this being a close election, binding/semi-binding and a very important question that affects everyone. One study in Norway showed that, at the local level, semi-binding referendums had higher turnouts of about 11%. I think that's a little too much to expect from this election because Norwegians are odd and because those results may partly reflect the likelihood of semi-binding referendums to be held for more important questions and partly be an artefact of low interest in local referendums in general. At the same time, this is a very high-profile issue so I don't feel comfortable discounting the effect too heavily. We should at minimum be able to expect a turnout over 60%. I'm gonna say 70% likelihood of turnout >/= 65% with my guess being 67% of registered voters. I think I'm more likely to be underestimating turnout than overestimating it. Both sides have run a fairly negative campaign and I've heard that negative campaigns tend to be associated with lower turnout but I'm not persuaded of a causal relationship there.

It strikes me how similar this UK decision is to our current presidential election here in the US.   Those who want to leave the EU are concerned about national identity and immigration.  In a sense, they think leaving the EU would "make the UK great again."   Much of the Brexit support comes from the economically disadvantaged,  those who feel left behind by this world of change being experienced everywhere.  In the US, we see a similar sentiment among supporters of Donald Trump. They resonate with his flag waving, us-first ideas.    The problem with these ideas is that they are mostly emotional.  There is very little logic in closing your borders and isolating yourself from an ever flattening world.   Individual country economies are much more reliant on the global economy than they used to be.  Just look at how even the possibility of Brexit is impacting the US markets.    Just like here in the US, I think that when most UK voters go to cast their ballots, logic will prevail over emotion.  Neither choice may be particularly exciting or appealing, but one is clearly more fitting with the integrated world of the future.

Feels close to call but here is some insight from betting market. My poll-based model implies about 64/36 (probability, not % of votes) for Remain (some arbitrary parameters I admit). Betting markets imply 76/24 (these are based on liquid two way markets). More interestingly, I had a detailed look at markets by percentage. These are less liquid so there is some approximation but here are the current markets by band (votes for Remain): 0-40 1.9%, 40-45 3.4%, 45-50 16.2%, 50-52.5 13.9%, 52.5-54.5 19.8%, 54.5-55 4.9%, 55-56.5 14.4%, 56.5-60 12.4%. 60-65 9.0%, 65-70 2.5%, 70-100 1.3%. (Bands are not of equal width because I used different sources). What does this mean? Market doesn't think it's very close with high confidence (i.e. small difference, low variance), it thinks it's much in favour of Remain but with significant risk in both directions (significant difference but high variance). Density peaks at around 54% for Remain which is quite big and 60% appears more likely than 45%! We shall see who gets closer, polls or markets but I thought I'd share this for those who are looking for more detailed clues. All calculations are approximate, in good faith and used at your own risk.

See http://www.wsj.com/articles/markets-ignore-the-brexit-worst-case-scenario-a-sterling-crisis-1466444823
By JAMES MACKINTOSH
Markets have fixated for the past week on whether Britain is about to vote to leave the European Union. Sterling, the euro, gold, global shares and even the yen have had synchronized swings as the prospects of such a “Brexit” rise and fall ahead of Thursday’s referendum.
Amid the speculation, little attention has been paid to the core assumptions investors are making. In particular, moves in sterling and in British government bonds, known as gilts, demonstrate a broad belief that the pound’s fall will be pronounced but not catastrophic, and that the Bank of England will ignore any imported inflation.
Investors mostly are brushing aside the prospect of a repeat. In the one sterling crash since the Bank of England gained operational independence over monetary policy in 1997—the post-Lehman depreciation when the pound fell by almost one-third—policy makers ignored the inflation which resulted. Instead, they cut interest rates to a record low, where they remain, to support the economy.
Sushil Wadhwani, a former Bank of England policy maker who runs a hedge fund, is concerned that after several years of stability a big fall in the pound could lead to more selling and feed on itself to create a sterling crisis. “This time round there’s a very good chance it becomes a vicious move [in the pound] at some stage because of the lack of hedging,” he said. If a fall in the pound turns into a downward spiral, the Bank of England could appeal to foreign central banks to help. But coordinated intervention would surely require the Bank of England to raise rates to help support sterling, too. This would be an extreme outcome, a true loss of confidence in the U.K. Even those who worry about it think it unlikely, just not as unlikely as markets suggest. :A handful of very small bets have been placed in the options market which would profit immensely from such a sterling crisis. The biggest was placed in April, an option with a face value of $100 million which would be in the money if the pound falls below 95 cents next month, from $1.46 on Monday. The previous record low was $1.05, hit in 1985 amid a crisis which forced the Bank of England to lift rates from 9.5% to 13.875% within a month to keep sterling above parity with the dollar" So  no way  sterling will collapse to 1.05. This is going to be a doozy.  Of the 23 polls taken since June 1 and reported in the Financial Times, "remain" won 8 and "leave" won 14, with 1 tie[1]. I took an unweighted average of these polls and got remain=43.73%, leave=45.59%, and undecided=9.95%. If we assume that all undecided voters either stay home or break for "remain" in the same numbers as the rest of the population, then this translates into a 37% of "remain" winning.  But there's some reason to think they *wouldn't* break this way. The average percentage of voters who identify as "undecided" in a "remain" victory is 11.75%, while the average percentage of voters who identify as "undecided" in a "leave" victory is 9.4%. Likewise, variance is much lower (2.8%) for "remain" than for both "leave" (3.7%) and "undecided" (4.1%). All of this suggests that the group of voters who vacillate between "undecided" and "remain" is smaller than the group of voters who can't make up their minds between "undecided" and "leave." That's bad news for europhiles. I know what you're thinking: High-level generalizations about these polls ignores the different modalities of these polls (Internet vs. phone vs. face-to-face) as well as the questions used, the quality of the pollsters asking the questions, etc. That's all true. And yet: 37%.  In the teeth of this mighty wind, Bloomberg's Brexit tracker is back up to 63% for "remain"[2]; PredictWise puts "remain" at 75% and climbing[3], and BetFair gives the UK a little more than a 76% of staying[4]. I'm inclined to defer somewhat to what I take to be better informed voices, but I have to admit that if I didn't think that leaving the EU would be a catastrophe for my unofficial home-away-from-home, then I would probably be far less inclined to do so. It is worth noting that one of the groups that strongly favors "leave" is the poor (as defined by The Economist, not me)[5], and there's a long history in both the US and the UK of less affluent voters being underrepresented at the polls[6]. In contrast, the rich (again, as defined by The Economist) favor "remain" by more than a 3-to-1 margin. That said, the elderly strongly favor "leave," and they're more likely to vote than the young who favor "remain" in roughly equal numbers[7]. This is especially true of ancient UKIPers[8]. So, yeah, this is going to be a real doozy.  --- [1] https://ig.ft.com/sites/brexit-polling/
[2] http://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2016-brexit-watch/
[3] http://predictwise.com/politics/uk-politics
[4] https://www.betfair.com/exchange/plus/#/politics/market/1.118739911
[5] http://www.economist.com/blogs/graphicdetail/2016/06/britain-s-eu-referendum
[6] http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0047272798000425
[7] http://pa.oxfordjournals.org/content/60/4/548.short
[8] http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/17457289.2011.588439

This is my first prediction but i have been following this referendum closely. Through out the referendum the polls have bounced around and ten days ago they were predicting that the Leave campaign had inched ahead for the first time by as much as ten points.  However throughout this referendum, the bookies have been firmly in favor of the Remain campaign winning.  In recent UK elections, polls have been wrong. Most notably in the 2015 General Election, pollsters were predicting that the Labour Party would win, but the actual result was a resounding victory for the Conservatives.  The general reason for this disparity has been attributed to the fact that people lied when polled as they were ashamed they were voting for the Conservatives (widely perceived to be the nasty party).  The same thing happened in the 1992 elections in the UK.  When people went into the voting cubicles last year, they decided to vote for less tax - despite the fact this meant greater austerity to the country.  The polls of the EU referendum have been confusing. They have mostly been in favor of the Remain campaign, but then began to swing in favor of Leave. I believe this is because Leave campaigners are very keen to get their voice heard. Remain campaigners are simply less motivated.  However, like last year in the general election I believe that when people go into the voting booths - they will vote remain as the status quo remains acceptable, the fear of the unknown will be too daunting.  In the last few days the assassination of a sitting Member of Parliament, by a right wing individual who proclaimed to want to put Britain First - an organisation campaigning for Leave  - has had a significant affect on the mood in the country. Coupled with blatant xenophobia if not down right racism displayed by members of the leave campaign,  has left confusion in the ranks of the Leave prompting some high profile defections. Many have been turned off.  Some believe that England's performance in the Euro 2016 football competition may lead to increased Nationalism if they go through to the next round on the 20th. And increase the chance of a leave vote. As English nationalists are most in favor of Leaving.  Nonetheless, Betfair, a firm that has taken in tens of millions of pounds in referendum-related bets, says the likelihood of a remain vote has risen from 65% on Friday to 72% on Monday 20th.  So with only three days to go, I think Britain will reject Brexit.  I think the split of the electorate will be 55% in favor of remain and 45% in favor of leaving.

Increasing my forecast from 55% to 80%.  The polls breaking for Vote Leave was concerning and I down weighted from 65% to 55%.  I wrote last time that there was risk of circularity in ignoring the polls and looking at the betting odds, as the bookmakers were also ignoring the polls and all of us were looking at Scottish referendum as the playbook for how the vote would turn out.  The tragic death of Jo Cox has certainly placed Remain in the winning position, witnessed by the swing in the polls back to Remain after the weekend.  I also noted before that in a fairly large, self-confident country like the UK, political campaigns needed to balance hope and fear issues.  A fear-only campaign can work in Scotland but not in the UK as a whole.  The Leave camp had nostalgia of "sovereignty" and old empire and the fear of unlimited "immigration", while Remain was unbalanced with only the fear issue of "economy recession", however with this terrible event last week, I believe the Remain camp has been able to catalyse its positive message.  This has been confirmed by David Cameron recent positive stance as well as his tweet of Jo Cox's final op-ed about the benefits of EU immigration for the UK.  Considering this was an issue Remain would not try rebut but reassure in public, I sense they are more confident of the mood of the majority in the wake of her death.   There has been a blistering  critique in the pro Leave press about any the use of Ms Cox's name or death during the rest of the campaign, but politics is a messy business about messaging.   The Vote Remain camp would argue to ignore and blank out her death would be equally demeaning for what she had been campaigning for and what she stood for "pro-immigration" and "pro-EU".   In politics, seminal events matter.  The UK is a secular, liberal society in the large political "middle" and I assume that is where the undecideds live.  The undecideds should swing to Remain more decisively as the implicit, anti-minority principles of the right wing elements within the Leave Vote are highlighted more vigorously in the press.  There is also a crescendo of business leaders and groupings of scholars/"experts" like Noble Laureate economists' open letter coming out in the past few days for UK to stay in EU.   In addition and probably more important, publications like the Times and Economist which are typically critical of the EU have come out for Remain.  (I think Rupert Murdoch is hedging his bets).  What is interesting about this activity of the Remain supporters is that its all coming out nearer to the actual poll date whether by design or in reaction to the previous weak polls.  One forecaster wrote presciently when up weighting his forecast precisely when polls had swung to Leave, stating and I paraphrase, the weak polls for Remain will reinvigorate campaign and create a sense of urgency for voter turnout supporting Remain which was one of the significant risks, an apathetic voting block.

In my first assessment of the likelyhood of BREXIT, I thought it would be a close run thing. It certainly looked like that to me until three days ago, but now no longer. Of course we still know very little for certain, with regard to  the motives and aims of her murderer, but there is no uncertainty whatsoever with regard to what MP Ms. Jo Cox stood for. For once, the social impact of this cowardly act of hatred seems to be determined by the goals that the victim chose for her life rather than by the hateful and malfunctioning toughtprocess of her murderer. I am not trying to style her into some kind of martyr. Her family would be ill-served by any such attempt as well as beeing completely unnessary. Mere compassion towards and sympathy for one good person being attacked and murdered out of hatred while serving the community as best as she could - that alone seems sufficient to shift this poll's outcome, and maybe even the fate of an entire continent. And well it should. I couldn't agree more.

I think the result of Ms. Cox' assassination will be increased determination on the part of both sides. "Remain" will be more determined because of the murder, "Leave" will be more determined because of the effort to associate their position with the murder. I doubt if it will change any minds on either side, and any effect the murder has will be to intensify opinions that voters already hold. I have thought all along that the worst possible outcome of the vote would be a very slim victory by either side. The losing side would almost certainly question the legitimacy of a momentous decision made without the consent of a large minority of the  voters. The murder of Ms. Cox makes the prospects even worse. If "Remain" loses, it will still consider "Leave" as being somehow complicit in the assassination, and if "Leave" loses, it will consider its position to have been unfairly tainted by a crime that has nothing to do with its policy prescriptions. Democracy relies in the losers of any given election accepting the legitimacy of the outcome. This would have been difficult for Britons in this case even under ideal conditions, but now the difficulty is that much greater. British politics might wind up as toxic as U.S. politics after this referendum.

Nudging down a wee bit, having rethought of the possible consequences for the referendum result stemming from the murder of Jo Cox. (1) There have been numerous unsubstantiated, and in some cases, blatantly false, attempts by elements in the media, and also from a few pro-Remain politicians, and even from at least one European Commissioner  to pin the murder either to "a supporter of Brexit" (news sources from outside the UK, in various European countries and Russia have been putting this line over even more).  While the motives of the murderer are confused and obscure, there is nothing in the public domain that suggests this is realistically the case. (There are documents that suggest an interest and some kind of involvement in neo-nazism - but by long distance correspondence in the pre-internet era  with groups in the USA and South Africa. The report that the murderer shouted "Britain First"  - which itself is disputed - has been put in a new light by the revelation that a witness who made this claim has been shown to appear on the (leaked online, several years ago) membership list of a rival (and less extreme) far-right group, the British National Party, which has a history of seeking to discredit the Britain First group..... There is also evidence to suggest a long history of mental illness on the part of the murderer, while it remains unclear whether Mrs Cox was his intended target or not. (2)  The only, somewhat gory and past precedent that comes to mind concerns the murder, in September 2003, of the Swedish Foreign Minister, Anna Lindh, who was a prominent campaigner in the referendum for Sweden to adopt the Euro. She was killed (in circumstances that also appeared very confused with motives not obvious) three days before the referendum. And despite the overwhelming "establishment" support for Euro adoption (as for Remain in the UK case), and the potential for a "sympathy vote", the referendum was still lost. Campaigning on the referendum has now ceased until Monday. (Small-scale elements - and I presume, but am not sure, the "get the vote out" door-knocking aspects - may take place over the weekend). On Monday Parliament has been recalled to pay tribute to Mrs Cox - which rules out campaigning on that day, while some other non-parliamentary organizations involved in the campaign (trade unions, for example) may be paying their respects to Mrs Cox on Tuesday. In effect this means that substantive campaigning on the ground may not take place until Wednesday - the day before the referendum. Still very difficult to interpret, in practice, what any or all of the above might mean for the outcome.  But any revelation (as seems, at least possible, or even probable) that the Remain side has attempted to misuse the murder for political gain, dishonestly and opportunistically, can be expected to count against their case.

Revised down to nought: No, a majority of voters will elect to leave, not remain. The dreadful killing of Jo Cox has led to campaigning being suspended. When it resumes, we can expect both sides to be rather more muted and wish to appear as responsible citizens – the fear mongering on both sides will abate. I would predict that her funeral and memorial service will not take place before Monday 27 June, ie., after the referendum vote. The question is: how much of a difference will this make to the outcome? There will be an increase in turnout from political ‘moderates’ who will see their vote as being in defiance of violence; they might increase the ‘Remain’ vote. But will it be enough to allay fears on immigration and the economic risk of leaving (which ‘Leave’ voters see as positives)? I doubt it. Left wing voters who support ‘Leave’ also see this vote as a method of ‘punishing’ the Right, believing it will bring down the Prime Minister and his Chancellor, tear the Conservative Party apart and leaving them critically wounded for the next four years, as well as giving Labour a reason to change its Leader – in other words, Left-wing ‘Leave’ voters are considering far more than just our membership of the EU. Barring a further externality, ‘Leave’ has won. the vote will be split 53% Leave / 47% Remain. EDIT: Parliament has been recalled on Monday 20 June for tributes to Jo. It looks as if the Referendum campaigning will either remain suspended or be relatively low-key until Tuesday. It will be interesting to see what the polls say over the weekend. Sadly, I remain of the opinion that 'Leave' will still win on Thursday. EDIT Monday 20 June: Having read most of the predictions/comments here, I'm surprised by how many people seem to place so much faith in the polls, given how inaccurate UK polling was at last year's general election. And remember, this is a referendum, not an election. Surely we ought to be looking beyond polling and the media in order to make the best possible prediction? I remain of the view that, in this case, the electorate are fickle and the vote will be in favour of Leave. EDIT Tuesday 21 June: having reviewed the forecasts made overnight on this site, I'm still surprised at how many forecasters put so much faith in polling, stock markets and bookmakers. This morning's BBC News suggests to me that the issue foremost in people's minds is still immigration, even though it's poorly understood: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-eu-referendum-36582391 I'm still forecasting that Britain will vote to Leave. Further EDIT 21 June: Having question other forecasters' over-reliance on polling, I've just come across this poll of UK motorists (OK, a 'special interest' group, but widely representative of the population who drive): http://www.fairmotoring.com/index.php?entry_id=1466445358 Still convinced that we're going to vote Leave on Thursday.

Even when polls were indicating a clear lead for In, this was a difficult call. I have long thought that the probabilities implied by the bookies (around 75% less a month ago) were too optimistic for In. Polls are currently indicating a very close call, possibly a lead for Out. Some issues to consider. (1) The press, very relevant in the UK, has been on balance favouring Out, business press favouring In. I will skip the detail but what matters is press with impact on swing voters. The Times coming out in favour of In as it is rumoured will have more impact than those who cater for the die-hearts. (2) Uncertainty increased by the fact that (a) parties are unclear in their message and (b) are not necessarily listened to. Labour comes across as unconvincing In, Lib Dems are absent from everything and the Conservatives are facing long-brewing fundamental internal divisions across all demographic dimensions. (3) Polls in the last Elections proved v unreliable for reasons still unclear. In my view, Out supporters have been a lot more vocal recently, shifting the argument almost exclusively to Sovereignty and Immigration. In comparison, In supporters are typically more moderate and less vocal. (4) In has conducted a poor campaign, particularly recently but appears to have won the economic argument clearly, hence Out has shifted to the Sovereignty/Immigration issues. However, economic risks still matter to most in a more direct way. (5) Private polls no doubt are taking place and their impact is seen in the betting markets which are now broadly reflecting fair prices.
On balance, I expect In to prevail but the risk of an Out vote remains significant.

http://europa.eu/rapid/midday-express.htm "Today the Commission adopted a proposal to set maximum wholesale roaming charges (i.e. the prices that operators charge each other for the use of their networks) in order to make sure that the end of roaming charges for consumers, set for mid-June 2017, runs smoothly. The EU agreed that as of 15 June 2017 Europeans will pay the same price to use their mobile devices when travelling in the EU as they do at home (see press announcement and fact sheet). For this important change to happen, the Commission committed to reviewing the wholesale roaming markets, and is today delivering on the plans agreed with the European Parliament and the Council.  "Vice-President for the Digital Single Market Andrus Ansip said: "In a year from now, we'll say goodbye to roaming charges. Our ambition is to abolish unjustified geo-blocking on the same occasion. We also want the cross-border portability of content to be a reality in 2017 so that Europeans can travel with their films, music, sports broadcasts, e-books across the EU. This will clearly be a triple win for European consumers".  "Commissioner for the Digital Economy and Society Günther H. Oettinger added: "We want to make sure that the end of roaming charges works properly for consumers and market players. This is why we come today with a proposal on wholesale roaming markets. We count now on the European Parliament and the Council to keep the pace and adopt it swiftly".   "As the summer holidays are getting closer, it is useful to remind that roaming charges have been cheaper than ever since 30 April: when travelling in the EU, mobile devices users only pay a small amount on top of their domestic prices: up to €0.05 per minute of call made, €0.02 per SMS sent, and €0.05 per MB of data (excl. VAT). These initiatives will be complemented by an ambitious update of EU telecoms rules in the autumn as part of the Commission's Digital Single Market strategy.

The trend recently seems to be to forecast down, but I'm more confident now than before that the UK will remain. Partly this is due to the impact of the Scottish and Northern Irish votes - both of which are heavily for remaining (part of the argument for staying in the UK was that Scotland would almost certainly be unable to rejoin the EU due to Spain's Catalonia concerns, and the Northern Irish border with Ireland would be negatively impacted by a spilt with the EU). William Hague (a consummate Eurosceptic) has spoken out in favour of remain with the argument that Cameron has dealt with future sovereignty issues with the EU already due to the pressure the UK gov was able to put on the EU over the threat of leaving. No new powers can be imposed without a vote of the British people, and the UK has been able to opt-out of things like the refugee quotas that are plaguing the rest of Europe. Add this to the tendency to vote the status quo, and the result will be remain.

I am reducing my forecast from 66%.  Looking at the forecasters here and the bookmakers, I suspect there could be risks of group think and circularity in the decision process.  Three important factors are raised consistently as a basis for this groups' forecasts to get to the average 70% probability, 1) the polls are not reliable, 2) the betting market is more reliable, and 3) the Scottish referendum.  Firstly I would make the assumption that polling methodologies have been improved since the Scottish and National election failures.  Secondly, the betting market is probably using the same factors we are using, polls are unreliable and Scottish referendum turned to No vote at the polling station, while late polls were signalling a surging Yes.  There is a lot of recency bias here.   But these are two different referendums with different hopes and fears.  I think it may be worthwhile weighing up the hopes over fears for Brexit.  Sovereignty and Immigration are the main hope and fear factors for the Leave campaign and economic deep recession is the fear factor for Remain.  The Remain campaign's biggest drawback is that neither Cameron nor Corbyn are true EU believers, so the campaign lacks that balance.  Unlike the Scottish referendum where Cameron government and the EU played hardball and stoked sufficient fear with Scottish and their small economy, the UK is a large economy and surely more confident in face of the risks and fears of the Remain campaign.  The UK also has a political and cultural history of "Splendid Isolation" from continental Europe and its affairs.  It helps being an island.  In conclusion I do think the polls may be more accurate this time and I do believe it will be a tighter contest than Scottish referendum.  The tendency of undecided people veering to the status quo at the polling station takes me to above 50% probability.

My gut feeling is that Leave now has a real chance of victory.

Regarding many forecasters' prediction that Britons will vote for the "conservative" option, if "Leave" passes we'll probably see videos of crowds in London waving Union Jacks and singing "Jerusalem." This is about as conservative as you can get in the UK. The EU can easily be seen as something antithetical to the status quo. The expansion of the EU since British accession in 1975 is an example of change, not stability, and it is unlikely that EU laws and regulations will not be imposed on the UK in the future. The "Leave" camp makes the case that the EU represents top-down, unaccountable, and never-ending change that imposes unacceptable obligations on the UK. You can agree or disagree with whether "Leave" is right about this, but there is no reason to necessarily consider "Remain" to be the status quo or conservative option. "Leave" is at least equally authentic as the conservative option, perhaps more so.
The latest newspaper polls suggest more of editor bias than public direction. At this point, I tend to go more with the odds makers, who largely given "Remain" a significant lead.

Using the same formula's I've been using, which takes the aggregated polls and disaggregates by population group and then weights the groups based on their turnout in the 2015 election, it shows a decrease of two percentage points in support for the "Remain" camp.  Overall, the polls have slightly increased for the remain camp, with those responding "dont know" reducing. It appears people are becoming more decided on which camp they are going to vote for. Whereas in the last set of aggregated polls on June 9th where the groups you expected to go heavily "Leave" did, in this set of aggregated polls, it showed a maintenance of those positions overall but a rise in "Leave" camp for Youth and Scots. This is a bit odd and might be polling. Either way it was a small decrease of 2 percentage points in the weighted equation.  A note on those significantly over 60% (or even 55%, really), these don't have any serious basis in the polls. In fact, the polls are almost all showing that the "Leave" camp is going to come ahead. At this point, you would have to allocate almost all undecided voters to the "remain" camp to get over 50%. Those predicting higher seem to be more hopeful than the situation shows. Also, If someone has better numbers on the Irish voting and the voting citizens that don't live in the UK, that would also be helpful to factor into the equation.

Referendums rarely result in change. Independence referendums in developed democracies have only resulted in change in 20% of cases (albeit small sample of 5).  The balance of power amongst power players in the UK is on the side of Remain. This includes the political establishment and the City. They are able to maintain a high public profile for the arguments of the Remain campaign, partly by harnessing the support of public figures of gravitas (e.g. Major, Blair, Brown, Heseltine), but ultimately their capacity to influence is mediated through the mechanism by which the question is resolved: it is a vote. Polls offer some insight into how voters may vote. A polls of polls (FT) has shown a relatively tight contest since the beginning of the year. The results vary according to how the poll is conducted (telephone vs internet) and how polls are adjusted for the likelihood of each voter voting. Telephone polls are thought to favour Remain because the option to choose 'undecided' (or whatever) is less clear than in internet polls, which is postulated to lead to conservative choices by undecided voters in telephone polls. Despite a tight contest in the polls, there are approx. 10% undecideds, who may swing the vote one way or the other. I expect Remain to benefit more from the votes of these individuals. That is because all large-scale change including Brexit is a large risk, especially for a country which is experiencing decent economic growth, and that undecided voters will view it as such. This will increasingly be the case in the days leading up to the vote as the markets become volatile (as they are currently), and as the press and politicians try to draw as much attention to the referendum and its risks as possible. Polling analyses show that low turnout will favour Leave, and high turnout will favour Remain. I expect the press and establishment to garner sufficient attention for the issue for the turnout to be (relatively) high. There has been some suggestion of a high intention to vote from the fact that voting registration has been reopened due to demand. A further factor to consider is the impact of the 2m expats living in Europe and the 6-7m living worldwide. It seems unlikely that these voters would be in favour of Leave, if they do vote.
Assuming that the 2m expats in Europe (4% of the electorate) vote (with UK rates of turnout), and are 60% in favour of Remain, this produces an extra 2.7% for Remain. Could I be wrong?
Turnout may be less impressive than hoped (the weather might be terrible, there may be too much indifference amongst undecideds). Bad weather might be the most significant risk here.
The elderly, pro-Brexit vote may have a better turnout than expected.
Events - a terrorist attack? But there are only 10 days left, and it's unclear what this would do to votes - it may push people towards conservative voting, or it may convince them that unity with Europe is preventing us from policing our borders, or it might scare them into staying at home rather than going to the polls. Another event might be something at the Calais camp - another mass attempt to breach the tunnel? Overall, there's not much time left for these rare things to occur.  Accounting for irreducible uncertainty: there are only a few days left, so such risks are small.

Shifting down a little bit - not so much in response to polls, as in seeing people coming out for Brexit that one might not expect to be in favour. I know that my hopping around is hurting my score, but it is unavoidable. Two things make it impossible for me right now to predict what the majority will do.
First, the "Leave" side has been gaining ground, even in the telephone polls, with the latest showing them in the lead. Online polls are still as uninformative as ever, showing no clear winner. Second, and more importantly: The tragedy in Orlando. We must take this into consideration. This is yet another terrorist attack on a Western nation, and the largest on US soil since 9/11. I imagine that this might have an impact. The question is: How much and in what direction? I have no doubt that both sides will immediately capitalize on this massacre to gain ground.
The leave side will argue: "See? We need to close our borders to protect ourselves better!"
While the remain side will argue: "See? We need to stay part of a large political union to protect ourselves better!" I am not fit to judge who is right about this, but let's try to consider the psychological effects of this: In times of uncertainty and trouble, people have a tendency to cluster together into tight groups, seeking protection from common ground. My assumption is that the people who want to leave will only see themselves strenghtened in their convictions, while the remain side will not gain any good ground from this. In addition, we can expect this to raise sympathy with groups who advocate for stronger border security, such as UKIP, which is staunchly on the leave-side.  I may also be wrong about this. People may decide that the only thing that can protect them is a stronger EU, but given the prevailing political climate in Europe, I highly doubt this. In light of all this, I am going to say 50% for now, with an update to follow, depending on which side the polls favor in the coming days.

The survey of 2,000 people by ORB found that 55 percent believe the U.K. should leave the European Union, up four points since  the last poll in April, while 45 percent want it to remain (down four points), according the Independent. These figures are reviewed taking into account the people’s likelihood to vote in the June 23 referendum. It is by far the biggest lead the Leave camp has enjoyed since ORB began polling the EU issue for The Independent a year ago, the newspaper said. It was Remain who enjoyed a 10-point lead then. Now the tables have turned. Even when the findings are not weighted for turnout, Leave is at 53 percent (up three points since April) and Remain at 47 percent (down three). The online poll was taken on Wednesday and Thursday. It suggests the Out camp has achieved momentum at the critical time ahead of the voting day. Differential turnout could prove crucial. ORB found that 78 percent of Leave supporters say they will definitely vote — describing themselves as a “10” on a scale of 0-10, while only 66 percent of Remain supporters say there’s no doubt they will turn out to cast their ballots.

Let's call this a 20% hit on young voters. In order to vote in the election, all voters need to register online. 90% of the UK has online access, and I'd assume that 90% of that is in the older segment. So that's a 10% hit on older voters. Splitting by old and young... 61y + 31o = 41 Remain
19y + 57o = 40 Leave
y + o = 1 y = 0.33 != 0.45 (call it 0.4)
o = 0.67 != 0.55 (call it 0.6) o2 = o*0.9/(y*0.8 + 0*0.9) = 0.63
y2 = y*0.8/(y*0.8 + 0*0.9) = 0.37 so the new distribution including the two age factors would be tilted 1% towards Leave. The news factor gives us another 1.4% towards Leave. So that takes us to maybe 60-70% in favor of Leave.

I wonder what the real significance of the "young people are registering to vote" trope is. I found this when I googled "UK youth unemployment:" http://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/SN05871 The graph counts people 16-24, but also breaks down the numbers into those 16 and 17 and those 18-24. The numbers for the latter group seem to track the overall number, which is given at 13.7%. So the real question is, who do young people blame for the 13.7% unemployment rate in their age cohort? It could just as easily be that they buy into the "Polish plumber" theory of job loss as it is that they want to affirm their identity as Europeans. So I don't really see how all these kids registering to vote necessarily presages a "Remain" victory. A lot of people make an economic argument for "Remain," but the economic arguments that voters really care about are the ones that affect their everyday lives.

A look at the British tabloids' coverage of the Brexit referendum: http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/10/world/europe/brexit-britain-european-union-media.html The first two paragraphs read: "Britons could lose control of their coastline. Their country could be scrapped or merged with France. And a nation in which tea-making is a daily ritual faces the prospect of a ban on its kettles. 
Over recent years The Daily Express, a newspaper with a print circulation of around 400,000, and its sibling, the Sunday Express, have made little secret of their antipathy to the European Union, presenting it as the source of a variety of such unlikely assaults on Britain and all things British." Later: "The tone of the coverage stands in stark contrast to the only previous referendum on Europe here, in 1975, when almost all the press was pro-European, including the popular midmarket Daily Mail.
Not this time. The paper has not so far unambiguously editorialized in favor of leaving, but the tone was set in February, when Mr. Cameron renegotiated Britain’s ties to the European Union, before recommending a vote to remain." We'll find out if the change in tone of the tabloids is a fluke or an indicator of public sentiment. But I think it's noteworthy that a certain sector of press opinion has changed, and the 1975 result doesn't necessarily register as the "conservative" choice for this referendum.

CONSENSUS PredictIt: 67%
GJP: 75%
Brexit Likelihood Score: 76% THE POLLS I trust Bloomberg's poll aggregation more than The Economist's because the former weighs polls by accuracy. The Economist may or may not weigh polls, but they don't state their aggregation methodology, which reduces trust. Bloomberg's Likelihood score comes from ncpolitics, which has it at 24% Leave. The number of undecideds seems very small. The poll margin is 3.3%, with 9.2% undecided. So in order for that 3.3% to close, two-thirds or more of the undecideds have to switch. The math is fuzzy, but either way, the Leave campaign has to swing a lot of voters to make up the gap. There are a lot of polls on this issue, so accuracy is greater, and therefore the consensus is more informed by poll aggregation accuracy than usual. GENERAL FACTS Spending seems to be relatively equal between both campaigns. The Brexit is complicated, so the populace is trusting leaders. SWINGS I was about to say a terrorist attack would swing the nationalist fervor, and could be a spoiler, but the Brussels terrorist attack actually correlated with increased Remain support, indicating some sort of European unity effect in the face of terrorist attacks. There was a big jump in Remain support around Apr 21st, which coincided with the Chancellor of Exchequer releasing an analysis of bad results for a Brexit. There could be more leaders and officials coming out in the final weeks to rally everybody to the Remain camp. SUMMARY The poll margins, the polls' trustworthiness, and the possible swing scenarios, lead me to lean the consensus further towards Remain than it currently is pegged at.

Peter Kellner (ex-Yougov) put out a piece recently which went through the results of 6 UK referenda from 1975's Common Market referendum to the 2014 Scottish Independence referendum - in all but one (the '79 Scottish Devolution vote) there was a sizeable swing towards STATUS QUO. Additionally, this discomfort w/ the previous 91% forecast is supported by the recent Nate Silver refusal to bend on GOP State of Indiana forecasts 2/3 weeks prior to the vote place DT in a lead position. Silver eventually made a last minute change to DT when hit over the head w/ additional evidence of a clear DT victory. I recognize we have two different Continents w/ extremely dissimilar cultural elements. However, flexibility under the circumstances is better judgement at this stage, without more clear & convincing proof of voter direction.  Thus, recent polls showing a  up clear tick in LEAVE campaign , which may change again, in the run up to the election has to be given greater weight. Second, am uncertain whether GJ participants are also, in some instances, falling into the common issue of "group think" malaise. GJI Superforcasters has an aggregated probability of leave winning the referendum at 15% &, wonder whether this problem has or has not infiltrated betting markets? NB: EVEN super forecasters are infallible. And, there is the risk that many would simply defer to their judgement. Additionally, it is equally understandable Superforcasters may be somewhat hesitant ( unless specifically requested to do so which is not required here)to disclose their sometimes valuable insight for protecting their work product advantages in such a competition.  It is a common issue but, one to consider as well ... There are enough "don't knows" for me to back off a bit. So, am coming down &, need to do more work on issue.

Four polls in the last week have shown a swing toward "leave," and markets, which perhaps had been complacent about a "stay" vote, have moved accordingly. Peak to trough this week, sterling fell 2 percent. Betting markets have also narrowed, while the latest Financial Times Poll of Polls suggests 46 percent for "stay" vs. 43 percent for "leave" — the 3-point gap is the closest it has been since February.
The erratic polling results are important. This is not a vote down traditional party lines. The Conservative Party is hugely divided, while as much as a third of Labour Party voters could vote "leave." Perhaps more importantly, in a referendum — as opposed to an election — the whole nation becomes a single geographic voting area, rather than 650 separate voting constituencies. So making traditional predictions based on small geographic strongholds always going to one party or the other is not possible. This vote is hard to predict, and with three weeks to go before the June 23 vote, markets are waking up to that fact.
"Leave's" initial momentum from February through most of May came because of a tactic dubbed "Project Fear." It has been widely known that turnout among "leave" voters would be very high — this in the once-in-a-lifetime opportunity they have been waiting for. Prime Minister David Cameron, who votes "stay," and his team need to make certain that enough people who support staying do in fact vote. He and George Osborne, who also votes "stay," have tackled this by making all sorts of scary forecasts about what an Brexit would mean for the U.K. economy. Their arguments appear to have been backed up by credible individuals such as Bank of England Governor Mark Carney, International Monetary Fund chief Christine Lagarde, and, most recently this week, by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. The tactic appeared to be working. However, in the last week, "leave" has fought back. The main catalyst is immigration. Boris Johnson, who votes "leave," leaped on official statistics that show net migration into the U.K. increased by 20,000 to 333,000 in 2015 — far above the limit of "tens of thousands" of inflows that Cameron once promised.

However you might want to slice the recent results showing a narrow lead for the "Leave" camp, it's pretty clear that come 23 June, a heckuva lot of Brits are going to want out of Europe. I doubt, however, that the end result will have much to do with the wealth of arguments and information - many folks, I'm sure, will vote with their heart and their guts, their reasoning based on one or two "facts" which confirm their biases. Resistance to change could still be the deciding factor, though there appears to be a more visceral response to this referendum than is usual. (I've lived through the Australian Republic and NZ flag votes in recent years, and both those motions were defeated because most people really didn't care one way or another. I don't think that's the case here.)

Based on my previous forecasts (and using the same equation of weighted groups - Age groups, Class, and Location - based on their turnout in the 2015 elections) with new polling numbers coming in to the aggregated Economist tracker (http://www.economist.com/blogs/graphicdetail/2016/05/britain-s-eu-referendum), I am revising my forecast to 49% from the 5/19 numbers which had my forecast at 54%.  What made the adjustment: Older populations have significantly decreased their support of the "Remain" campaign. Rich support of the "Remain" campaign has gone down 7 points. Northern England support for the "Remain" Campaign has gone down 14 points, while Southern England has remained relatively steady. Overall, from the 5/19 numbers, every category has reduced support. This could be a polling issue but with aggregated polls collected by The Economist, this should mitigate some of these polling errors. Therefore sticking with the originally formulated equation, the forecast is 49%. I will revise when new numbers come in.

Phone polling indicates a comfortable lead for remain, internet polling indicates just narrow lead if any. However, for me it looks like that the leave campaign is systematically overstated by the internet polling. It might be that the remain side overstates social liberal voters and academics (which tend to be Bremainer), but from what I can see the leave campaign is highly polarized while the remain side is clearly not passionate and more focused on economic benefits. Since the internet polls are self-selective the danger of overstating leave is a way higher than the risk over over-representation of academics / social-liberals in phone polling. Other indicators also tend to show a good chance of winning for remain (betting odds &  forecaster like number cruncher & status-quo-oriented voting behavior in  referendum votes). Apart from that: Northern Irish-voters (mainly remainer) and expats (probably mainly remainer) are systematically excluded from the polling. Major risks are low turn out (especially the Glastonbury Festival and the summer vacation for students in general; not the European Football Championship since it seems that strong football supporters are not really decisive in terms of taking a stance for or against Brexit) in the summer which affects mainly Remain-support and some potential for the occurrence of harming events as terror attacks (European Football Championship in France) & a worsening of the Euro-Crisis. There is also some potential of harming the remain side caused by the cancellation of the EU-Turkey-Agreement on the migration crisis. Without these factors (realistic likelihood of harming events & lower turnout) I would say something between 88-92%.

MY COMMENT: There are so many reputable voices speaking against a leave the EU and giving good reasons (below), that it must sink in with the population eventually The UK's exit from the EU would have a global effect, which could hamper trade, investments and jobs, the G7 has warned. Following a meeting in Japan on 27 May, the leaders released a summit declaration referring to a Brexit as a "risk to global growth". The comments, which come less than a month before the EU referendum vote, classified a Brexit alongside geopolitical conflicts, terrorism and refugee flows as having a potential shock of a "non-economic origin". http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/g7-summit-brexit-risk-global-growth-1562281?awt_l=NJT0v&awt_m=irMwNOXK7WbOvKU&utm_source=email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=rss - Following a decision to exit, the UK would need to negotiate the terms of its withdrawal and a new relationship with the EU—unless it abandoned single market access and relied on WTO rules, which would significantly raise trade barriers. It seems likely that ratification of a new deal would require unanimous consent of all EU member governments, making agreements subject to considerable political risks. As EU-level agreements also cover the UK’s trading relationship with 60 non-EU economies (and prospective arrangements with another 67 countries are in the works), the UK would also need to simultaneously renegotiate these arrangements, or else see them revert to WTO rules.
- Another risk is that markets may anticipate such adverse economic effects, provoking an abrupt reaction to an exit vote that effectively brings these costs forward.
- London’s status as a global financial center could also be eroded, as UK-based firms may lose their “passporting” rights to provide financial services to the rest of the EU and much euro-denominated business may over time move to the continent.
[these points are taken from the latest IMF Article IV Consultation on UK http://www.imf.org/external/np/ms/2016/051316.htm ]

A recent ORB poll showed the Remain campaign in the lead by 13 points among people who definitely intend to vote. This is at odds with polling from major UK pollsters who use larger sample sizes. The 3 current polls are confusing.  For instance, ORB has Remain 14 points ahead, Opinium has Remain in the lead by just four points, the same as YouGov. Both companies use sample sizes twice as large as ORB. Another pollster, ICM, had Leave in the lead by four points two weeks ago on a sample size of 2000. But ORB typically just uses 800 people, and reading deeper into the data, it becomes hard to see how this could be representative of British public opinion. For instance, ORB seems to have spoken to just 32 people in the North East, just 57 people in social grade D, just six black people (one male), and just six unemployed people in the entire country. Most persons I have spoken with indicate Leave as the favoured option but it is historically correct that British people tend to like the status quo, as proven by the recent Scottish Referendum (where the polls were some way out as they werre with the General Election but essentially they were correct, not wholly wrong). Television appears to favour more Remain exposure, the Labour Party  generally favour Remain as do the Scottish National Party. I go for 85% forecast for the above reasons

It's looking worse and worse for the "Leave" campaign. There are two important factors to consider: First: Yes, the average poll sees the two sides neck-to-neck. But, I think it's important to be careful when considering which polls are reliable. One important trend is immediately visible: Online polls are around 50:50 when it comes to who will win the referendum. However, telephone polls consistently show that the "remain" side is more popular. For a variety of reasons, I consider telephone polls far more reliable than online ones. Most of these reasons boil down to *who* fills out these polls. A telephone poll can be taken from anyone who has a phone and is willing to answer the question asked by Gallup, YouGov or whoever is asking. That means that we have a more statistically robust cross-section of the population, since almost everyone owns some kind of phone (old and young, male and female, left or right, libertarian or authoritarian). Online polls are different. They are filled out by the people likely to A: Go online and B: Fill out an online poll. This matters, because online polls usually favor the portion of the population that is most motivated to go out and announce their opinions. But the loudest in the room do not have to be the most numerous. Most of the time, people who are for a change of the status quo are the most motivated and the loudest, but are often (though not always) in the minority. So it is here two. From the polls, I believe we can conclude two findings: A - The average British citizen, when asked, will choose to remain with the EU. B - The people who want to leave are more motivated, but less numerous. Elsewhere in life, sheer determination can count for much, yes. It may be argued that the determination of the "leave" side is what made this referendum possible in the first place. But in a referendum this close, motivation and ambition count for little. Numbers are all that matter. So, I am assigning 2/3 that this referendum will go in favor of "remain". Personally, I think the "leave" side is doomed, but we must leave for several factors, including unexpected events and the possibility that the people from the "leave" camp may be more motivated to go out and vote. We shall see...

COMMENT: I was quite sure that from now on a stream of bad case scenarios if leaving the EU would be in the press.

With online polls (like YouGov's) tending to show a narrow lead for 'Leave', while telephone polls mostly show a narrow lead for 'Remain', public opinion seems finely balanced, and turnout is clearly going to be critical. There are two key forces to weigh up, where turnout is concerned: 'Leave' voters have a much higher average age, and we know older voters are much more likely to turn out to vote. But 'Remain' voters have a much higher average education level ('Remain' has a 30% lead among university graduates), and more educated voters are *also* more likely to turn out. According to Anthony Wells of YouGov, these two forces roughly cancel out. So with finely balanced public opinion, and little to guide us in terms of turnout, why am I 75% certain that 'remain' will win? My answer in three words: "status quo bias." We saw in the Scottish Independence referendum that undecided voters broke for 'Remain' at a disproportionate rate. So if the 12% of voters currently self-reporting as 'undecided' prove equally likely to prefer the status quo, that should be enough to tip the balance in favour of remain.

Both sides have been producing implausible scenarios, but the Leave group seems to be putting forward particularly weak arguments; every voter must know by now that their £350 million a week saving is wrong, but they keep using this same wrong figure, they also know that Turkey will not be joining the EU in the next 4 years (if ever) so their credibility is evaporating. On the other hand I doubt that many people are convinced by the Remain claim that house prices will be 10% to 18% lower after a Brexit. In the last week the polls - in particular the telephone polls - (and betting odds) seem to be moving towards Remain (as many people suspected it would).

A number of folks here have drawn out attention to a recent article at the Guardian in which one is told about "a widening disparity between phone and Internet polling, with one producing a 10-point lead for remain and the second reporting that the leave campaign is ahead by four"[1]. What to make of this? One possibility is that both of these polls are outliers. An unweighted average of polls this month has both "stay" and "leave" at 43%, with "undecided" at 14.3%. That's close to the April numbers: "stay" = 44.43%, "leave" = "41.71," "undecided" = 12.38%[2]. The Guardian phone poll has "stay" at 47 and "leave" at 39 (which is an eight-point spread, not a ten-point spread as the quote above says, I must have missed something), and that's about 1.5 standard deviations from the mean for "stay" and about the same for "leave." The Internet poll was less out of line with the numbers we see elsewhere, with only "leave" more than a standard deviation away from the mean. I don't know enough about the merits of phone vs. Internet polling to have an informed opinion, but my best guess is that we don't yet have enough experience with Internet polling to speak to its accuracy in any reliable way[3]. Maybe I'm too pessimistic; who knows? So that was something of a dead end, I think. But another way to try to get traction on the Brexit question is to look at party membership. The same Guardian piece gives us the following breakdown of UK party membership: UKIP: 13%
Torries: 36%
LibDems: 7%
Labourites: 34%
ScotNats (SNP): 5%
Greens: 4%
Other: 1% Let's assume - why not? - that voters turn out for the referendum in numbers proportional to their party membership. (Will they? Probably not. But it's not a terrible working assumption.) I'm willing to bet that UKIP is all in for breaking with Brussels, so that 13% for "leave." What about the ScotNats? This is a trickier question than I imagined. It might seem like a no-brainer for members of the SNP to vote for an exit to the EU and then follow that up with a second referendum on Scottish membership in the UK[4]. But SNP leadership is painfully aware that (i) losing a second referendum so soon after losing the first would probably cripple the independence movement for a generation (see Quebec) and (ii) the ScotNats might not yet be in a position to win[5]. In fact, some who favor Scottish independence would like to see it be part of the EU! (That's not as odd as it might sound. Scotland has a long and troubled history with England, but that doesn't mean the Scots wouldn't want voluntary shared governance with other European powers.) So there's no clear reason (that I can see) to think that ScotNats will vote overwhelmingly for Brexit. Indeed, one recent poll suggested that the Scots (who are not the same as members of the SNP, of course) favor remaining in the EU 3-to-1[6]. That gets us up to 15.5%. The Tories seem deeply divided over Brexit - another anglophone conservative party in jeopardy because of a populist uprising[7]? Take these numbers for whatever they're worth, but according to one recent poll, "45 per cent of voters said [pro-Brexit Troy Boris] Johnson was "more likely to tell the truth about the EU than [anti-Brexit Tory David] Cameron, while 21 per cent said the opposite"[8]. Boris has, as we know, said some extraordinary things of late: "Napoleon, Hitler, various people tried this out, and it ends tragically. The EU is an attempt to do this by different methods." For reals, ya'll. That's the voice of truth, according to 2 out of 3 Tories. Well, suppose they do break for Brexit in slightly lower numbers - say 3-out-of-5 Tories vote "leave." That gets "leave" up to 37.1%. The Greens look like a pretty solid bet to vote "stay," since EU environmental protection and regulation is bound to be much better than anything you're likely to get in the UK alone[9]. The same is true, mutatis mutandis, for bankers and their City cronies, who are no friends of the Party of Kermit [10]. Suppose then that the Greens go overwhelming for "stay" but a few vote "leave." That gets "leave" up to 37.75%. It's hard for me to suss out exactly what the LibDems are up to. Some of their leadership has made noises up the increased strain on the NHS if the UK leaves the EU[11]. LibDemster Tim Farron has called pro-Brexit thought leaders "downright pathetic"[12]. Suppose the LibDems go for "stay" in roughly the same numbers as the Tories go for "leave." That gets "leave" up to 40%. What about the Laborites? "Nearly two thirds of Labour voters say they are likely to vote to Remain – around six million people," according to one source[13]. That sounds pretty good until you realize it also means that one third of Labour voters say that they are likely to vote to leave. Even if Jeremy Corbyn is able to step up - no sure thing as he's rather ambivalent about Brexit [14] - that still means you've got 51% voting "leave." So...wow...goodbye to all that. Or not. All that was very back-of-the-envelope. But it's not crazy. I might have (okay, I'm sure I do have) some of the numbers wrong. Once again, a problem caused by the wording of the question:  In elections that are controversial or involve lots of people who can't decide, spoilt ballots are not uncommon.  If Stay pulls 49.9% and Leave pulls 49.8% and .3% of ballots are spoilt, Stay will win, which is what I suppose to have been the intent of the Q, since the outcome and not the margin is what has policy implications.  However, "a majority of voters" will not have supported it.  As it happens, that is precisely the proportion of spoilt ballots in 2015. In 2010, about 1% were spoilt.  In an election with only two choices, this can be critical indeed. I am proceeding on the assumption that the intent of the Q is some version of "Will Stay prevail?" and not what the words actually say, but I am increasingly frustrated by the inability of these characters to say what they mean--unless they mean to care about the majority as such, in which case they simply have no idea at all of why people participate in this stuff, or even what is important in the actual world.   I am prepared to apologize prettily and profusely if the call actually requires a majority and is not first-past-the-post, like most elections. Please let me know if that is the case; I am preparing my remarks for that occasion. http://www.votenone.org.uk/spoilt-ballot-results-2015.html
http://www.votenone.org.uk/protest_votes_count.html

An anti-Brexit opinion piece from a Labour MP: http://heatst.com/uk/the-patriotic-case-for-remain-jess-phillips-mp/ I find it interesting that the piece is headlined "The Patriotic Case for Remain," thereby conceding to some degree that so far the "patriotic" position has been for "Leave." I'm not sure pro-Brexit voters would find the author's analogy convincing: "It is my patriotism that makes me want to stay in Europe. I want Britain to be the biggest and best it can be. I want to have all the influence.  I want us to be part of a gang that makes us stronger, makes our voice louder.  I want us to eat our dinner at the grown up table. I want to be at the party where the decisions are made, not the person crying in the kitchen because the popular gang didn’t let us play." Comparing Britain to a kid trying to make friends isn't really analogous in my opinion, and I'm not sure that particular appeal to emotion is terribly powerful compared to the well of traditional patriotism that "Leave" proponents can dip into. And there's this at the end:  "Never in all my working or personal life has going something alone, without friends been a choice I would make. I believe in the power of a group to achieve things, even when some of that group does my head in. Doing things alone is always slower, less productive, and more doomed to fail." To which the emotional appeal of a "Leave" proponent would be: "Did we care about being alone after Dunkirk?" That answer may not have much to do with modern reality, but the author's subjective observations about going it alone don't have much behind them either. I think this particular attempt to appeal to British patriotism is a failure, and pro-EU Britons should stick to practical economic arguments. I'm not sure such arguments would prevail, but the pro-EU side attempting to play the game on terms dictated by the anti-EU side is a losing proposition. There's no St. Crispin's Day speech about the glories of common regulations for small and medium-sized enterprises. Pro-EU people should play to their strengths, and not pretend that they can match the emotional appeal of the "Leave" side. If anything, such attempts make the "Remain" side look weak and defensive about their patriotism.

Using a ~310 year analog of ~1706 suggests rising British success/strength and eventual withdrawal from Continental affairs, eg. the rise of the Tories in 1710 and eventual end of the War of Spanish Succession by 1714 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_of_the_Spanish_Succession). Expect Britain to play it's classical part as enforcer of a European balance of power, while abstaining from close ties..

Bank of England Issues Starkest Warning Yet on ‘Brexit’
U.K. could face financing difficulties if a vote to leave EU spooked foreign investors, BOE says
A vote to leave could cause households to put off spending, businesses to delay investment and push up unemployment, officials said. Such an outcome would also likely lead to a sharp fall in sterling, pushing up the cost of imports and fueling faster growth in prices. The U.K. could also face “a major financing difficulty” if a vote to leave spooked the foreign investors on which the nation depends to fund a yawning gap between what it spends and what it earns, the BOE said. Speaking at a news conference, BOE Governor Mark Carney said that a vote to leave the EU could push the U.K. economy into a “technical recession,” or at least two straight quarters of declining output.

Aggregate polling has definitely shown an uptick in Leave vs Remain. Telephone polling shows a persistent clear bias to remain, although online polling has more fluctuation. General online polling seems to have resulted in a clear pickup in leave with a worrying decrease in "I Don't Know" (IDK). If you focus on YouGov polling, however, Remain seems to have the upper hand. I prefer the YouGov online polling because I believe that they have a more sound approach to developing their surveys than other polling firms. Some polling firms, in fact, seem to exhibit clear biases, like ICM. So every poll that gets reported does require significant inspection.  I am beginning to believe that the real consequences of Brexit are lower than many people have suggested. While there is certainly going to be short term uncertainty and adjustment, a great deal of the modeling has difficulty taking into account the potential changes in the economy that will result as some of the UKs trading relationships with the UK shift. The accepted wisdom seems to be a 1% reduction in GDP for some period of time, but I have a hard time believing that this will be a permanent shock. Thus, some of the economic arguments against Brexit may not be effective.  To the last point I am most concerned that the "Bremain" camp still lacks an argument that stirs fire in the bellies of the populace. The sovereignty argument proffered by Brexit supporters is inspiring, if fallacious, in a way that the economic argument is not. I believe it to be fallacious for 2 reasons: 1) the UK has not ceded complete governing authority to the EU and 2) in a globalized system countries yield sovereignty to supranational organizations in order to participate in the global system. These, however, are nuanced points beyond what can be fit into a sound bite. The sound bites, from esteemed former parliamentarians like Nigel Lawson, are much more stirring. Although Lord Lawson's arguments are non-existent, the difficulty of explaining the absurdity of the sovereignty argument allows it to remain compelling.  I am revising my forecast upwards because the ramifications from the Paris attacks were not as long lasting or as large as I thought they would be. I think that the inertia of the status quo will win the day, but I think the market under prices the real risk of Brexit and that the May 27th purdah could impact the Remain camp's position.  http://whatukthinks.org/eu/questions/should-the-united-kingdom-remain-a-member-of-the-eu-or-leave-the-eu/ A more eloquent exposition on the argument of sovereignty

This may wind up having some significance: "Muslim Labour leader favored to win London mayoral race" http://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/muslim-labour-leader-favored-to-win-london-mayoral-race/ I know that the London mayoral race has nothing directly to do with Brexit, but I'll warrant that the religious and ethnic identity of London's mayor has some relationship to the perceptions of ordinary Britons about the future ethnic composition of their country. Again, immigration from Commonwealth countries has been going on since long before UK admission to the EEC/EU, so the two issues are politically, and even logically, unrelated. But I don't think that matters. The question of a UK exit from the EU will not be determined by reasoned economic or political arguments; it will be determined by emotional appeals. And these emotional appeals will be on both sides. On one side, you'll have an appeal to British identity, on the other side to multiculturalism and "the future." It will be interesting to see what Britons outside London think if Khan is elected. Surely Khan will get a large number of ethnic Britons to vote for him, but I think the preferences of Londoners might not be an indicator of the attitudes of Britons overall. I should add that I think that if Khan loses, Brexit is still, in my opinion, a real possibility. But his election might make it more likely, since it could reinforce the "take our country back" sentiment.

An FT article that (finally) treats nationalism as something other than a pathology: http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/24e7a462-0d52-11e6-b41f-0beb7e589515.html The author of the article is correct that nationalism is a comparatively new phenomenon; the "earliest adopters" of nationalism did so in the 18th century - Britain, or anyway England, somewhat earlier. You can also date to the 18th century the ideas of a liberal political order, with natural rights that the state is obliged to respect, and the right of people to choose their system of government. These ideas are intimately related. The "nation" is a community of people bound together by language, custom, and common founding myths or "national epics." Once communities of people began to see themselves in these terms, the state took on a new identity: the state derived its legitimacy and authority because it acted as the agent of the nation. Prior to this, monarchs had been sovereign; now "the people" were sovereign. Authority didn't derive from God or tradition; even monarchs ruled by permission of their peoples (as Charles I and Louis XVI found out). From the beginning, nationalism could be used as an excuse for horrific oppression in the name of "the people." Exclusion from the political community that was identified as "the people" often resulted in persecution of those excluded. No denying that, and I wouldn't attempt to; but nationalism is also associated with the rise of individual rights, if only within the sharply circumscribed definitions of the "nation." This is because if the "people" were the sole source of political legitimacy, there had to be a mechanism by which they could make their will known, and so we had free speech, elections (restricted to members of the nation, and not even all of them), etc. Prior to the rise of nationalism, governments (at least in the west) were considered agents of God, or a dynasty, or a religion, or some abstraction. With nationalism, governments were regarded as the agents of a specific community of human beings (albeit by definition exclusive ones). Moreover, in the two to three hundred years since nationalism became the most widely recognized organizing principle of government, every other organizing principle has been considered suspect or deficient. Nations might adopt a liberal human rights regime, and consider all persons to have "inalienable" rights. But even so, a national government was only obliged to act on behalf of its own people. In fact, acting on behalf of another people was a breach of a national government's fiduciary duty. It might align and cooperate with other national  governments, and it was bound by its agreements to them, but other nations and governments had no moral claim to demand favors, protection, or resources from any other nation's government. A national government was responsible only to its own people.  I think opposition to the EU in Great Britain and elsewhere derives from the perception that the EU is not acting as the agent of Europeans as a people. For example, the EU commitment to human rights is a commitment to the abstraction of human rights, universally applied. The trend in European countries for the past two centuries has been to reject the idea that governments have a responsibility to take care of people outside of their sharply defined political community. This may be good or bad, but in my opinion this is the issue. That's why I'm not sure that economic arguments will be conclusive in this referendum. We may find that this referendum is about competing theories of government.

Caveat: I am pro-EU so my forecast might be unknowingly biased.
This is a hard one to call though and what seem to be strong arguments and interventions from the pro-EU side and international organisations, etc., don't seem to be having the effect on public opinions one might expect. I'm voting for yes though because of:
- motivated reasoning (on the side of the anti-EU camp - I think these voters may be more 'certain' or motivated, thus their point of view appears in the media more and there's more self-belief)
- Combination of status quo bias, 'floating voters' and reticence of both a large section of pro-EU voters and the average Brit (no serious stereotyping intended here, but as a half-Brit both myself and other Britons can be reserved about our opinions) to declare either their pro-EU stance or to be definite about their stance, whatever it may be
- Cross-political moves e.g. Labour's Corbyn supporting the EU (changing his previous apparent stance), Cameron (Conservative) making a recent deal with trade unions, who have now come out supporting the EU (there was a strong sense of scepticism in their ranks). What makes me unsure:
- Motivated reasoning as above - may translate into more anti-EU voters going out and voting (combined with fairly low voter turnout in general in the UK)
- Adding to above, recent changes to voting rules here mean many might not be registered to vote; evidence suggests this might affect e.g. young people/students disproportionately, who seem based on polls to be pro-EU - hence lost votes for this side. Also if my predictions about floating/status quo behaviours above bear out; 'uncommitted' people might be less likely to register/vote and subsequently vote 'in' due to status quo/uncertainty etc.
- A genuine distrust of politicians and of Europe (coupled with undoubted European weaknesses and failings) has been exploited quite well by the anti-EU side; leading to both left and right wing camps opposed to EU for different reasons.
- Apologies for this countrymen; but Britain's political history over the last hundred years hasn't been particularly cooperative and the 'don't tell me what to do' mindset coupled with a 'we'll tell others what to do' mindset shouldn't be underestimated in terms of how it could lead to a 'no' vote as a perceived reflection of 'sovereignty', 'reflection of our place and confidence in the world', etc. (don't be offended here if possible or immediately think of counterexamples - of course there are counterexamples - but try to see my comment as reflecting strands of thought which may be contributory to outcomes here).
