Are there do-overs in this league? After a bit of reflection on my last forecast, I think further revision is in order. The central thesis of my last forecast was that, if we squint really hard, we can probably see the beginning of the Renwick effect[a]. I now think that I was mistaken. We might or might not see the Renwick effect in the future, but we're not seeing it yet. Or at least _I'm_ not seeing it yet, which is a somewhat different proposition.  Why the change of mind? Using the metadata from "The Financial Times"[b] we see that  ***the average results for the Brexit polls in April (so far) are as follows: stay=42.75, go = 40.83, don't know=14.58. 
***the average results for the Brexit polls in March were as follows: stay=42.87, go=40.50, don't know=18.75. 
***the average results for the Brexit polls in February were as follows: stay=43.38, go=39.38, don't know=15.77[c]. I grant you that I'm taking all of this data at face value and not attempting to weight for the reliability, size, or temporal proximity of the polls. I leave that to smarter folks. But I just don't see what I thought I saw: the beginning of a shift toward the status quo (i.e. stay in the EU) that the Renwick effect predicts. In fact, we see a very slight movement _away_ from the status quo, though I think that the size of the shift is too small to mean much. What's most remarkable to me is the stability of the opinion polling data over the last 3 months. (It would be super-freaking-awesome if someone tried to determine whether this level of stability prior to the referendum predicts a greater or lesser degree of variability in the final weeks before the referendum, but the low sample size might render this information less than fully helpful.) You know, this one might be a nail-bitter, folks. -- [a] https://electionsetc.com/2016/03/14/first-forecast-for-the-brexit-referendum/
[b] https://ig.ft.com/sites/brexit-polling/
[c] So "stay"+"go"+"don't know" doesn't always equal 100% in the average of polls because it doesn't do so in some of the individual polls that the FT reports. That's odd; this seems like an exhaustive trichotomy, but I don't think it makes too much of a difference to the outcome.

The GJ consensus forecast has started to climb, largely on reports of recent polling data[1]. Color me *a little* skeptical though. The average of the 12 (12!) polls taken in April (as reported by "The Financial Times"[2]) shows less than a 2% gap between thems that wants to stay and thems that don't: 42.75% = "stay" and 40.83% = "go." Of course that leaves 14.59% who haven't made up their minds. If you assume that the undecided won't break in large numbers for either of "stay" or "go" (and I don't know of any evidence that counts strongly against this assumption), then "stay" gets 51.1% of the vote, and "go" gets 48.8%, with a standard deviation of a little more than 4%. That gives us about a 61% chance of "stay" winning, and that seems too close for comfort.  But maybe the numbers shouldn't be taken at face value. So I tried weighting the polls for temporal proximity. I gave those polls done within a week a weight of 1.0, those within 2 weeks a weight of 0.75, those within 2 weeks a weight of 0.50, and those done at the beginning of the month a weight of 0.25. The average outcomes  barely changed: "Stay" = 51.5%, "leave" = 48.5%, but the lower standard deviation (2.6%) predicts a much higher probability of a victory for "stay": 72%. And I also tried giving more weight to the polls that have larger groups of respondents, roughly giving a poll that has 3 times as many respondents 3 times as much weight. Yes, I know that's a pretty naive approach, but what ya want for free? The results were "stay = 51%, "go" = 49%, with a standard deviation of 2.2%, and a 67% chance of victory for "stay." Things look better for "stay" than they did a month ago, but not as much as the GJ consensus forecast would suggest. Of course, it might be that the consensus forecast is higher because people expect to see the Renwick effect[3]. I do too, at least to some extent. But my understanding of the Renwick effect involves the shift being visible in the polls in the time leading up to the referendum. Maybe we're starting to see it, maybe not.

Hat tip to @dada for pointing out this report in reply to a comment I made yesterday: http://www.cer.org.uk/sites/default/files/smc2016_20april2016.pdf The report gives a great deal of information about the economic impact of Brexit, and it appears to me to be even-handed regarding pro and anti positions, even though its authors make no secret of their anti-Brexit leanings. I've said in the past that I am skeptical that macroeconomic arguments will necessarily sway the voters, as opposed to the experts. I give two quotes from the report below, with my comments. Both refer to immigration to the UK. p. 90: “The best evidence we have, then, suggests that to the extent EU free movement raises unemployment among the UK-born at all, the effect is small; it goes away after a few years as the labour market adjusts; and is strongest in recessions.” Comment: The impact may be small in macroeconomic terms, but people don't live their lives in macroeconomic terms. You can't say to your creditors that you'll pay your bills "after a few years as the labour market adjusts." p. 100: "However, recent studies have found that immigration has caused local house prices to fall. There are two reasons for this. First, migrants 
tend to live in more cramped conditions than do Britons. Second, the researchers found that when immigrants move into a local area, Britons move away, and so demand for housing falls in the short term. However, Britons will push up prices in the areas they move to, and in the long run, migrants are likely to move into less crowded accommodation. This will push up housing costs – unless Britain builds more houses – especially in the south-east of England." Comment: What this means in practical terms is that migrants are crowded into ghettos that Britons don't want to live in or near. You can say this is bigoted, but that doesn't affect the reality of it, and ordinary people will consider this reality when they vote. This is more than an economic issue; it's a matter of people's perception of social cohesion. Advocates of the EU make the argument that the Union helps to suppress nationalist impulses. If the above is correct, that isn't true; it merely localizes those nationalist impulses, and instead of disliking or resenting foreigners in adjacent countries, you dislike and resent foreigners in adjacent neighborhoods. I am not saying that Brexit is a good idea, or even that it will pass. All I am saying is that what we read in the newspapers, or in think tank reports is written by people who belong to an educated, financially secure, international class that is insulated from the policies that it advocates, implements and maintains. If enough average Britons already think the existing arrangements don't give them any advantage - and perhaps put them at a real disadvantage - the arguments made by this international class will not convince them. I keep reading articles and op-eds about what business people and academics say about staying or leaving, but all I hear from average people is poll numbers, which may be misleading (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bradley_effect). Perhaps a better indication of what's happening outside the think tanks, universities and office towers can be seen here: http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3518689/Applications-British-soar-EU-migrants-fear-kicked-Brexit.html This is indirect data from a tabloid, so take it for what it's worth. But those Romanian and Bulgarian migrants live side by side with everyday Britons, not economists and bankers, and the migrants are hedging their bets. I don't think there is any way of knowing what the actual support for Brexit is.

Going up to 90, for two main reasons.  (1) Plenty of big guns and effort out on the Bremain side (the Government leaflet distributed to every household last week: now Obama - who is broadly liked and respected in the UK -  chipping in firmly on the Bremain side). (2) Meanwhile, the Brexit campaign is seriously stumbling - despite the "sane" pro-leave group being the one with backing from the Electoral Commission as the lead campaign group. (And also having seen them, and been impressed by how they are acting locally where I live.)    Michael Gove (a respected and serious figure - and most importantly not a "swivel-eyed loon") proposed the notion in an interview that the UK's relationship with the EU might be akin to that of Bosnia or Albania - which is not going to impress anyone - while Vote Leave leader Dominic Cummings gave a terrible show of himself at parliamentary questions - essentially admitting that his financial arguments for Brexit had been drawn up on the back on an envelope and bore little resemblance to reality. Plus his immense arrogance and disregard for rules and regulations and indeed other people came over very strongly, as reported in the Spectator. Add to this the incumbency/status quo advantage, and it's hard to see how the Brexit side can get out of this hole and get ahead.

This referendum bears many similarities to the previous referendum, however this time: the Conservative Party holds a majority government, rather than the Labor party; Britain contains, and has benefited from extensive inter-Europe migration (~2.6 million EU citizens based on a 2012 estimate); following the crash of oil and the stock market around 1975, the UK reported weaker economic growth and higher unemployment relative to other EU nations then, vs. today; finally, the Labor government was divided regarding the issue of leaving the European Economic Community in 1975, just as the Tory government appears to be divided on the issue today. In 1976, 67% of Britons chose to remain within the EEC, with only a couple of remote electoral regions overwhelmingly opting to leave; today there is less incentive for Britons to want to disengage from the EU, hence I expect Britons to be more in favor of remaining within the EU now, than they would have in 1976.

http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/brexitvote/2016/04/14/turn-out-or-else-do-referendum-campaigns-actually-change-voters-minds/ WHAT I LEARNED:
1) Remain is slightly in the lead in telephone polls 2)Leave is slightly in the lead in most online polls. 3) There is generally a small shift towards the status quo in the final weeks. 4) Earlier polls tend to overestimate voters' desire for change. 5) Campaigns do sway voters, so how the issues are shaped by each side matters. 6) Remain is emphasizing fear of disruption Brexit would/could cause 7) Stay is emphasizing fear of EU control of UK:  appealing to national identity and sovereignty and threats of immigrants 

8) " . . . the so-called “losers” of globalisation, those with lower levels of education and working class occupation, are more likely to be opposed to the EU, whereas the “winners” of globalisation – e.g. highly educated professionals – are much more favourably disposed.    9)" For those who say they will vote to stay in the EU, the argument that we’ll be worse off economically if we leave the EU generally carries greater weight than for those who intend to vote to leave. 10) "Yet the losers of globalisation face a dilemma: on the one hand they are generally more critical of the EU and more concerned about immigration, but on the other hand they have the most to lose financially if a Brexit vote causes economic disruption, as they are often in a more vulnerable position in the labour market. A focus on economic arguments, rather than cultural or political ones, is thus likely to boost the Remain side." 11) The popularity of each campaign's main messengers matters, also.  Cameron has been a great asset for Stay, but his dwindling popularity is a concern.  12)  Survey evidence from YouGov and other polling organisations has shown that individuals who oppose membership are more likely to vote than those who want Britain to remain in the EU.   13) Moreover, older Britons are significantly more Eurosceptic than younger ones, and we know from general elections that age matters to turnout, since the young are much less likely to turn out. This could give a sizeable advantage to the Leave side, especially if this is a low-turnout referendum.

Polls show the vote being quite close, with perhaps a slight lead for remain.  I do think there are a few factors which make me think that the remain side is more likely to win than polls currently indicate. 1) Telephone polls generally show a relatively sizable lead for remaining, while online polls show the two sides being very even.  While the reasons behind either or both types of poll being wrong are complex, I am guessing that the true sentiment may lie somewhere in between the two. 2) There are still a lot of undecided voters.  I think that they will tend to break more towards the remain side since the short and medium term outcomes of leaving the Eurozone are somewhat uncertain, so voters will opt for the seemingly less risky option of staying.  This is similar to what was seen in the Scottish Independence vote where the No vote won by a larger margin than the latest polls leading up to the vote indicated.

The Number Cruncher Politics Brexit probability index is the index that combines the polling average with analysis of the likely accuracy of polls and data from the past referendums to project a probability distribution of outcomes. It takes into account the change in and volatility of public opinion in the run-up to past referendums with a particular focus on referendums relating to the EU. The index represents the modeled probability of a vote to leave. http://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2016-brexit-watch/

WILL DAVID CAMERON'S CRISES BOOST BREXIT?
BY JOSH LOWE ON 4/8/16 AT 11:26 AM
http://www.newsweek.com/david-cameron-brexit-tata-steel-panama-papers-ids-resignation-445522 A string of crises have hit U.K. Prime Minister David Cameron’s government in recent weeks, potentially damaging the campaign to keep Britain in the European Union ahead of a June 23 membership referendum. This week, it was continued questioning over Cameron and his father’s finances that had the usually-unruffled politician on the front pages for all the wrong reasons. Before that, it was the malaise settling over Britain’s once-proud steel industry , when Indian Tata steel said it would be withdrawing from its British businesses, risking thousands of jobs. All this came after the resignation of former Work and Pensions Secretary Iain Duncan Smith, who in an extraordinary interview on the BBC’s Andrew Marr Show said the government was in danger of “drifting in a direction that divides society rather than unites it.” ... Campaigners on both sides might be expected to play up the impact of individual events. Matthew Goodwin, professor of politics at the University of Kent, says that criticism of Cameron over his finances in particular may not have much impact, as “the suggestion that David Cameron is part of a wealthy elite is already priced into British politics.” But, he says, “we know that dissatisfaction with the government is on the rise… that is significant as a backdrop to the referendum, especially if we remember that referendums are often influenced by general opinion toward the incumbent government of the day.” While, therefore, Cameron’s crises may not wildly swing the vote towards Leave, they are, says Goodwin, “not particularly helpful” for the Remain camp. So whether Cameron drives significant numbers of votes away from Remain or not, what’s certain is that he has been much less of a boon than some expected to the Remain campaign....

@Anneinak draws our attention to a fantastically interesting paper by Alan Renwick (who teaches at one of my old stomping grounds, the University of Reading) in which we get a pretty persuasive argument. The conclusion of the argument is that in major referenda like the one coming up on whether or not Britain will remain in the EU, support for the "yes" position tends to decrease quickly in the months and weeks leading up to the referendum itself. This bar chart (from Renwick's piece) does a pretty good job of laying out the evidence[c]: (https://pythagorassite.files.wordpress.com/2016/03/renwick___don_t_trust_your_poll_lead___in_cowley_and_ford__2014__pdf.png?w=978) I feed the numbers into a spreadsheet (though I had to do a little guesstimating because of the lack of granularity along the vertical axis), and it looks like the support for the yes/change side of the referenda drops in the month or so before the event on average by 11.6% but with high variability: 14.7%. The whole thing looks something like this: (https://pythagorassite.files.wordpress.com/2016/04/screenshot_4_1_16__6_37_pm.png?w=920) Let's take this at face value and see what we find. We could start with the Financial Times, which has some nice meta-polling data, represented in the first graph above[d]. An unweighted average of the polls taken so far in March results in 0.46 for staying in the EU, 0.42 for leaving it, and 0.12 undecided. Let's leave the undecided folks out of the picture, just as Renwick does. (I assume that the bias toward to status quo is largely a result of undecided types coming in at the last moment with a vote for keeping things as they are. I can't recall whether Renwick's paper addresses this matter, and I'm too busy/lazy to look through it again.) That means that we're looking at a probability of about 0.52 (=0.46/(0.46+0.42)) of staying and a probability of about 0.48 (=0.42/(0.46+0.42)) of leaving the EU. It looks like what we're supposed to expect on average a -11.62% drop in support for the a "yes" result in the referendum (i.e., a result that leads to a change in the status quo). In this case, that's a drop in support for the Brexiting to 0.425 (0.48-(0.48*0.1162)) and, conversely, an opposition to Brexiting of 0.575 (1-(0.48-(0.48*0.1162))). This would be an overwhelming win for the forces of sanity over the eurosceptics, in my humble opinion. Given the standard deviation is 0.06 (=14.69 % of 0.425), the range of expectation looks something like this: (https://pythagorassite.files.wordpress.com/2016/04/normal_distribution_calculator_with_step_by_step_explanation.png?w=978) So if this model is correct, then we should expect a mere 10% (or so) chance of a vote to leave the EU. But is the model correct? Several reasons for doubt concerns the data points themselves, though there are ways to try to account for these concerns. First, many of the referenda took place in nations with very small (by global standards) populations, and small populations make polling very difficult. Sweden had only 8 million citizens in 1980. Ireland had only 5 million citizens in 1986. I expect that polls for a country of 65 million citizens in 2016 are likely to be a bit more predictive, all other things being equal. I suppose that the best way to try to take this into consideration would be to discount polls taken in smaller countries. As I have no principled way to do this, I won't try. But I'd be pleased as punch if someone else did.  Second, several countries had many referenda. Bloody Ireland! How many referenda do you need, mates? Yes, democracy and all that, I suppose. But still.... Anyway, we can easily control for that by removing multiple referenda in a single country and replacing them with a single average for referenda in that country. The results look like this: (https://pythagorassite.files.wordpress.com/2016/04/screenshot_4_1_16__9_47_pm.png?w=920) As is obvious, the results are less dramatic, though only slightly so. We should expect 5.2% less support for Brexit at the polls on June 23, down to 42.8%, with a standard deviation of 6.3%. That leaves about a 13% chance of the pro-Brexit forces getting for than 50% of the vote. Using Olympic rules (tossing out the highest and lowest scores) tames the data even further. We should expect 4.9% less support for Brexit at the polls on June 23, down to 43.1%, with a standard deviation of 5.4%. But it still means less than an 11% chance of Brexit. I assume that Renwick is himself is making some data-shaping modifications similar to the one's I'm playing with here, since he himself is (as of the date of this writing) giving Brexit a 13% chance, as you can see from his blog. (https://pythagorassite.files.wordpress.com/2016/04/first_forecast_for_the_brexit_referendum___elections_etc.png?w=978) Another reason for doubt concerns the similarity between the kind of referenda used to build the model and the referendum to be voted upon in late June. In some cases, the referenda are very similar to what's going on in the UK right now, viz., the Danish referendum of 1992[e]. But the 1980 Swedish referendum on nuclear power and the 1997 Welsh referendum on creating an assembly with devolved powers[g] are less so. The way to handle this, I think, would be to create a similarity scale which would allow us to discount the importance of referenda that are less like the Brexit referendum on the horizon. But I work (more or less) for a living (again, more or less) and don't have the time on my hands right now. Finally (not really finally, but this is the last thing that came to mind while typing this up), there's the matter of local issues that might matter. I don't know, e.g., much about Swedish elections (and that's an understatement), but perhaps there are typical patterns of voting that are true in Sweden but are not true in the UK that have relevance here. Maybe Swedish voters regularly are especially risk averse at election time but not so prior to the election, while UK voters aren't. Who the hell knows? But if I were going to put all my eggs in this particular basket, I'd want to find out.  All that said, I feel fairly confident that this tendency to shift toward the status quo is real, and it's made me a lot more confident that Britain will vote to remain in the EU. So I'm moving from 61% to 71% likelihood of the UK voting against Brexit.  -- Endnotes [a] and [b] removed. [c] http://centaur.reading.ac.uk/38059/1/Renwick,%20'Don't%20Trust%20Your%20Poll%20Lead',%20in%20Cowley%20and%20Ford%20(2014).pdf [d] https://ig.ft.com/sites/brexit-polling/ [e] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Danish_Maastricht_Treaty_referendum,_1992 [f] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swedish_nuclear_power_referendum,_1980 [g] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welsh_devolution_referendum,_1997

Yougov (see links below) Despite the relative closeness in the polls, I still lean towards "remain" for a number of reasons:
1) My assumption (borrowing somewhat from Prospect theory): people are generally risk averse, and a lot of the "Leave" camp will either switch to "remain," or many undecided will ultimately decide to remain. When push comes to shove lots of voters will opt for status quo, since a radical break from the UK increases uncertainty in trade, security, immigration, other issues, and is therefore relatively risky to remaining.
2) While the deal that Cameron is shopping was initially viewed as negative, he was nonetheless able to whip votes back to his camp against what was considered at the time to be fairly stiff headwinds with the Scottish referendum, so there is some recent precedence in his ability to do so. This is also somewhat in line with my prior rational that UK's elites have historically (going back to 19th century w/ PMs Disraeli & Gladstone) been able to persuade public opinion with big national security interests, and a unified Europe is a more secure one vis-a-vis extra-European security threats (at least from nation states).
3) This interesting polling analysis indicated that, despite peoples' opinion on the referendum, there is more wiggle room to the "remain" side than "leave": https://yougov.co.uk/news/2015/12/10/eu-polling-soft-leave/
4) This other interesting polling analysis indicated that, despite peoples' opinion on the referendum, UK citizens are generally more bearish on UK's prospects leaving the EU, which somewhat confirms 3).  All told, I believe my initial 75% was too far to the right given public opinion polls. All things considered, however, I think the likelihood of a "remain" vote remains greater (pun certainly intended). I will continue to monitor polls, specifically "undecided," as well as Cameron's success shopping the deal he secured. That plus any terrorist threats in EU that could stir  nationalist anti-immigration sentiment in UK in favor of "leave."

Current public opinion supports (just barely) remaining in the EU, and I expect  that number to increase in reflection of the Conservative and Labour parties' pro-EU stances as the referendum draws closer.  Additionally, I would suggest that supporting a Brexit position is a deliberate act of rebellion by many of those polled, whereas when faced with the stark choice of potential instability and economic losses vs more of the same within the EU, the majority of voters will stick with the "known knowns."

March 24 polls (http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/eureferendum/11617702/poll.html) suggest a 52% yes, 48% no. As a result, 52% is my initial estimate. I wouldn't aggregate a higher percentage due to older data, but the trend ("yes" winning) seems consistent. Having in mind that the average Telegraph reader is 18% more likely to vote NO, I will raise the 52% to 55%. Taking also in mind this report (http://d25d2506sfb94s.cloudfront.net/cumulus_uploads/document/l2qxf3d9pp/YG-Trackers-Europe-Referendum-070316.pdf), I hold the 55% with marginally higher confidence. Now, I think that the polls are underestimating yes for three reasons. (Assumption 1.1) First, polls are (I think) conducted in Britain (obvious, but important). This means that British people working in other countries do not participate in said polls. (Assumption 1.2:) I find it reasonable that the latter would vote YES. The second reason has to do again with the polls. I think they are (Assumption 2.1) being conducted in hours that lead to an underrepresentiation of certain categories of the working force (i.e. investment companies, etc). I find that (Assumption 2.2) the majority of these categories would be pro EU. Finally, I believe (Assumption 3.1) that the undecided will lean toward the result that promises less change. Time to put weights. For the second reason, I estimate that the effect (if real) will be minimal. So let's go to 57%. The first is easier to estimate. The total turnout in the 2015 elections was at a high 30.7 million. Now, there are 1.3 million Britons living/working in the EU. (Assumption 4.1) I doubt any more than 10% would go to vote, I even doubt 5% will. As a result I renew my figure slighly up to 59%. Along with the third reason ("undecided"), I will raise it to 62%. Before closing, I would like to factor in an outside influence: the EU. As the time closes in, I believe the latter (Assumption 5.1) will lean towards British positions even more than they already have (federalists are already crying inside). I'll give a 5% to this, and get the final estimate to 67%. The reason I'm afraid to give any higher percentage is that I don't know how much the rhetoric for either position will appeal towards its respective base. I (would-be assumption 6.1) believe the NO rhetoric to be stronger. Also, I think rationality will not play a vital role in this referendum (after all, measuring the effect of Brexit would be extremely hard).

Sure, the terror attacks in Brussels are likely to make a difference to *current* public opinion regarding the Brexit vote[a][b][c][d]. But will they make much difference come June 23? There is some evidence that suffering a terrorist attack can have long-term affects on voters[e]. Terrorism may increase voter turnout levels[f], and there's some evidence that it causes voters to skew right a bit[g]. Moreover, the 2004 attack in Madrid seems to have had an impact on the election there, helping to cause Spain to disentangle itself from commitments that made it more vulnerable to terrorism[h]. However, that attack took place a mere three days before voters went to the polls. But I doubt that Brussels is a game changer for Brexit. All of these studies focus on cases in which the polity has been a direct victim of terrorism, and an attack on Brussels is not an attack on London, at least as far as the average British voter is concerned. Moreover, the terrorist attacks in Brussels didn't teach anyone anything fundamentally new. Without much evidence, I suspect that British voters already had a pretty good idea of what they might be in store for after November 13.  I'll keep an open mind, but right now I can't see the recent events in Brussels having much of an affect on the Brexit vote.  --- [a] http://www.politico.eu/article/brussels-attacks-change-brexit-climate-nigel-farage-leave-stay/
[b] http://time.com/4270362/how-brussels-will-affect-brexit/

The polls of polls that I found (http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/eureferendum/11617702/poll.html) give remaining in the EU a slight advantage (51% to 55%); however, they also suggest that up to 15% (and up to 20%) of British voters are undecided, meaning the vote could sway either way. It is unlikely that all undecided voters will swing one way or the other, especially given that even when "leave" takes the lead, it is only minor and for a short period—it seems that British voters generally favour staying.  Another source of information is betting lines, which favour staying as well. "Stay " odds range from 2/5 to 1/2 with a median of 4/9, while "Leave" odds range from 13/8 to 2/1 with a median of 7/4 (http://www.oddschecker.com/politics/british-politics/eu-referendum/referendum-on-eu-membership-result & http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/eureferendum/11617702/poll.html). These odds are much more strongly favoured towards staying and given that, in contrast to polls, betting odds require people to put money down on their bets, I am more inclined to favour these statistics. Overall, they seem to work out to a prediction of about 68% chance of staying in the Euro.  Finally, given that no country has ever left the Euro, the concessions the Euro has given to Britain, and a status quo bias, I raised my prediction from the above baselines to 72%. Status quo bias is a powerful force and will only be overcome by a very strong opposite reaction (we saw that in Canada in our last Federal election).

This won't be an in-depth forecast. I'm just revisiting my earlier forecast and trying to determine whether there are good reasons to change my mind or to stay put. The polls remain pretty evenly split, with those who want to remain in the EU slightly outnumbering those who want to leave[a]. The betting market gives, as of this writing, Britain a 55% chance of remaining in the EU[b], which is more-or-less in line with the polling numbers. The GJ take on things, however, is the odd man out. It's consistently forecast a 75% likelihood that Britain will remain in the EU, though just in the last few days it's dipped to 72%[c]. Now, we're starting to see elites - especially from the conservative side of the aisle - start to freak out in much the same way that Republican party elites are doing so over our Trumptacular presidential primary here in the States. The Financial Times, for example says that "Britain is heading for Brexit"[d]. And Fortune interprets the departure of Ian Duncan Smith as the beginning of a Tory "civil war"[e]. Smith's protestations that his departure has nothing to do with his sympathy for Britain's withdrawal from the EU have convinced few if any[f]. Guys, who ya gonna believe, me or your own two eyes? The best reason (as far as I can see) for thinking that Britain won't leave the EU is that it would be giving itself the gift of an economic disaster: "Leaving the European Union would cause a serious shock to the UK economy that could lead to 950,000 job losses and leave the average household £3,700 worse off by 2020, a report commissioned by the CBI business lobby group has warned. In a stark warning, an analysis conducted by accountancy firm Pricewaterhouse-Coopers for the CBI said that Brexit could cost the UK economy £100bn – the equivalent of 5% of GDP – by 2020 and would cause long-lasting economic damage from which it would never recover"[g]. Okay, you convinced me, friends. But it's not so clear that the British median voter is going for it. Reasons to think that people vote for their economic self-interest have been hard to find recently in English-speaking democracies[h].  So I'm changing my forecast slightly to be more closely in line with both the polls (about which I'm leery given some less than spectacular results of late) and the betting market.  -- [a] http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/eureferendum/11617702/poll.html [b] http://www.oddschecker.com/politics/british-politics/eu-referendum/referendum-on-eu-membership-result [c] https://www.gjopen.com/questions/149-will-a-majority-of-voters-in-britain-s-upcoming-referendum-elect-to-remain-in-the-european-union [d] http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/35bef41c-ecfe-11e5-bb79-2303682345c8.html [e] http://fortune.com/2016/03/21/british-government-brexit-divisions-eu/ [f] http://www.ibtimes.com/eu-brexit-debate-2016-iain-duncan-smith-says-resignation-not-about-referendum-2339816 [g] http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/mar/21/brexit-could-cost-100bn-and-nearly-1m-jobs-cbi-warns [h] http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/29/opinion/sunday/voting-and-self-interest.html

http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/mar/20/britons-on-europe-survey-results-opinium-poll-referendum There's treasure trove of data here that you can slice and dice in a dozen ways, or more.   The poll was done just prior to the conclusion of Cameron's negotiations with the EU partners. One thing that concerns me for "stay" is that the question. . . ". . .  is a much more significant issue in the eyes of those who back Brexit (50% of whom select it as a major issue) than those who wish to remain in the EU (15%) and it is an issue that increases in importance with age; just 12% of 25-34-year-olds say it’s a big issue compared with 53% of those aged 65 or over. There are sizable differences on the basis of political party affiliation; Ukip supporters are, predictably, most likely to consider Europe to be an issue of great national importance (59% do) and the same is true of 40% of Conservative supporters. However, just 15% of Labour supporters and 9% of Lib Dem supporters concur. There are also interesting regional variations; while Londoners are the least likely to identify Europe as an important national issue (16%), Britons living in the rest of the south-east are the most likely to deem it important (43%). It also shows:  Stay = 40%, Leave = 41%, Undecided = 19% In the last 6 months momentum has been with Leave: 16% moved to Stay, 22% moved to Leave, and 62% didn't change their opinion.  "The fluidity of public opinion raises the possibility that unforeseen events could contribute significantly to the final result." "In the context of a tight race, the ability of each side to mobilise its supporters on polling day is likely to be crucial. In this respect, the older age profile of Brexit supporters becomes a strong advantage; 88% of those aged 65-plus say they will definitely vote compared with just 34% of 18-24s and 39% of 25-34s. Furthermore, 76% of Leave supporters say they will definitely vote compared with 59% of Remain supporters. There could be sizable regional variations in turnout; Londoners, who are more likely to vote to remain, will need the most persuading (45% will definitely vote). In contrast, 72% of those in the remainder of the south-east, who are more likely to be Leave supporters, will definitely vote. ". . .  those who believe that EU membership is good for Britain (47%) outnumber those who believe it is bad (35%) by a significant margin.  "Immigration is, by some distance, the issue most likely to affect how Britons will vote in the referendum; 49% say it will influence how they vote, and this figure increases to 72% among those who will vote to leave. It is not, however, the main issue among Remain supporters, who are more likely to cite both international trade (35%) and the state of the UK economy (34%).  There's much more data.  Combined with other articles and polls I've seen, I think that this is going to be a squeaker, so I'm lowering my forecast to 55% from 66%

This is my first "proper" assessment of the situation, my previous forecast was mostly with the crowd but with little consideration of the topic. It looks like Remain has the edge, historically. A careful reading of the Wikipedia page on secession (Sorry, couldn't find another list) turns up arguably 20 unsuccessful secession movements, versus 16 successful[1], giving a historic base rate of 55.55...% There is reason to be uneasy about the pollsters. In the 2015 General Election, the pollsters failed to predict the outcome. There have been many post-mortems of this, but it could simply be that they got it wrong due to chance. Everyone gets things wrong from time to time due to chance. So, assume the polls have a 5% chance of getting the outcome wrong. Current polls[2] place it at 51% to remain in the EU, but it's hard to apply Bayes Theorem, since we don't know the likelihood of the polls outputting this condition! I do, however, take on board @AndrewSabisky's caution against putting too much emphasis on these numbers. Further, the Telegraph stated that "Leave voters are more likely to say they will show up – 79 per cent say they are certain to vote if the referendum was held today – whereas 72 per cent of Remain voters say the same. Taking this into account, Leave (52 per cent) has a seven point lead over Remain (45 per cent)."[3]. This gives leave edge in a departure from the historic tradition! On the fourth hand, people are generally risk seeking with regards to potential losses and risk averse with regards to potential gains[4]. I think that people are more likely to take the "sure thing" of existing economic and political situation, even if the expected rewards of leaving are greater. This does assume that the public see the referendum in these terms. Maybe fear will overcome some of the Leave voters when they're actually in the booth? Averaging the 3 data points above gives us a probability of 50.51%. I think that we should bump it up due to Kahneman's prospect theory, and potentially even some more due to the reasonably heavy media campaign for remaining. However, we should not get overzealous and bump it up by too much. I give it a 56% chance, all in. References: [1]: Secession, Wikipedia, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secession Accessed 2016-03-17
[2]: EU Referendum Poll of Polls http://whatukthinks.org/eu/opinion-polls/poll-of-polls/ Accessed 2016-03-17
[3]: Remain or leave? It all rests on the risk factor http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/12194138/Remain-or-leave-It-all-rests-on-the-risk-factor.html Accessed 2016-03-17
[4]: Kahneman, Thinking Fast and Slow, Penguin 2012

again, I caution forecasters not to over-interpret polling data, given the big polling miss in our last general election. For a general feel of the crisis in UK polling at the moment, see https://yougov.co.uk/news/2015/12/07/analysis-what-went-wrong-our-ge15-polling-and-what/. This referendum is even tougher to poll than a general election (in some ways, though it is a binary outcome, which helps). It's just not easy to figure out who the desired population to sample is (likely referendum voters). Elections happen once every 4/5 years & so it's not too difficult out who election voters are, though even this proved beyond the wit of the pollsters in 2015. This referendum is a one-off event and so turnout is going to be a real bitch to model accurately. Will low-information habitual non-voters show up in droves, motivated by nationalist feeling? Or will turnout be very low because no one really understands the issues or knows what's going on? These are not questions with obvious answers... Despite the clear read for Remain showed by phone polls (which have had a better record than online polls in our last few elections/referendums), caution is advised.

At the risk of overreacting I think it is important to note the well covered ORB poll in the telegraph today.  This is the first telephone poll of which I am aware that shows Leave taking the lead. That is important because A) we are operating under the assumption that telephone polls are more accurate,  B) I think polls will far and away be the most important inputs to a forecast, and C) telephone polls have consistently had Remain in the lead on telephone polls. It is also important to note that, to this point, the average number of "I Don't Know" (IDK) respondents has been around 15% and this poll only had that number at 4% While I have made a small adjustment downward in my forecast I think this may be overreaction more that anything:
1) again this is the FIRST telephone poll to suggest Leave is in the lead
2) the pollster ORB has only conducted online polls for this topic to this point their recent online polls now have leave in the lead while other pollsters either have remain or a dead heat.
3) ORB's previous online polls never let room for undecideds, voters had to choose Leave or Remain. It could be that undecideds moved from Remain to IDK on this poll, but we don't know This poll also provided more data on intention to vote. The Telegraph headline, and their commentator Sir Lynton Crosby are suggesting that this is where the rub is and that when you factor voting intention in the Leaves carry 52% to 45%. Again, given while I think this is an important data point it is the first phone poll to show this so we need to take it with a grain of salt. So, moral of the story, slight revision down but need more confirming evidence that this is a trend. Leaving an economic union like the EU is a pretty rare occurrence, and very rare for a large stable country like the EU. The only examples of countries actually leaving the EU (actually its predecessor the EEA) are Algeria, which declared independence from France, Greenland, which remains a dependency of Denmark which is a member of the EU, and Saint Barthelemy an overseas department of the French government. None of these are even remotely comparable to the UK. OPEC has had some defections although OPEC is not an economic community in the way the UK is, most defectors have returned, and generally the defectors are weak nations that feel they are not getting much benefit from OPEC despite paying large fees. Other examples of states/Economic union break ups seem to be rooted in ethnic struggle, which is not something we are seeing with the UK. Thus, there is limited historical precedent for an event like this. 
The EU has a long history of euro-skepticism in government that ultimately gets shot down. In 1974 the ascendant Labour government had campaigned on a promise to hold a referendum on EEC accession. The ensuing debate looked remarkably similar to today’s debate. The Labour cabinet was split on supporting remain vs leave. Ultimately a new agreement with the EEC was reached and, in the first nationwide referendum ever, the British people overwhelmingly voted to remain a part of the EEC. Certainly Britain’s economic position relative to the rest of Europe was a bit different in 1974 than today but it is interesting that the tone and nature of the arguments seems to be so similar. 
There are three things that have me concerned as I watch this:
1)	Polling credibility. After both the Scottish referendum and the 2015 Parliamentary elections polling in the UK was more or less shredded from a credibility perspective. For one, they were flat wrong, and two there were significant differences between online and phone polling. It will be essential to monitor the volatility of these series and their direction going forward. 
2)	The arguments being posed by both sides are not salient to real voters. The Remain campaign’s website has a few snippets with limited additional factual evidence. There is a seemingly credible element about the true “cost” from a dollars and cents (I know they don’t use dollars) perspective to leaving the trade union and how it would hit the pocket books of consumers, otherwise it is pretty weak. The leave campaign, while disorganized, has arguments that a much more salient for individual voters. I am also having trouble reconciling some of this trade stuff. Goods trade appears to be covered by the WTO and remain campaigners suggest that services will not be covered, but as signatories to the GATT the UK and EU are signatories to GATS as well. So how will single market access for services be affected? 
3)	My small sample of Londoners amongst whom I have conducted my own non-scientific polling are all pretty pessimistic. The most common line of reasoning I hear is “If you were the UK today would you vote to join?” that’s a red herring but people don’t seem to care. 
The Remain campaign is going to have to convince the undecided voters to vote to remain in order to secure victory. I think that there will be some moderate success there but current polling seems to be pretty clearly signaling remain. I think that the volatility of the current polling, although they may be somewhat unreliable, is what will drive my forecast going forward.

A similar problem lies for the business lobby, in that big business is pro-EU, however, again if it pushes too hard it would be seen as 'interfering' in the people's will - big business is not popular in the UK. Small businesses are less involved in foreign trade, so will vote more in line with general cultural views on the referendum, rather than being a pro-lobby so to speak. A few key pro-EU voting groups will also be excluded or minimised from the elections. Ex-pat Brits, who you would assume are generally more pro-EU, especially those living in the EU, are not allowed to vote in the if they have lived away from it for more than 15 years, whilst those who legally are still allowed to vote will find it extremely difficult. Most don't live in owned-properties, and instead rent, and move regularly, making it more difficult to register to vote, so tend to have lower voting statistics. I'm basing a lot of my rationale on the way events turned out in the Scottish independence referendum in September 2014. Being a Scot in Scotland and so also witnessing the events of that referendum firsthand, I felt that two things had an enormous amount of influence on the outcome which may draw a parallel with this referendum, and these were the media coverage of events and the economic arguments, both of which in 2014 seemingly affected Scotland to vote marginally to remain in the UK and both of which I believe will sway the British people to remain in the EU.  Media coverage of Brexit in the big papers has so far seemed to carry a (sometimes tacit, sometimes not) sentiment against leaving the EU. The politically centre-left and highly influential newspaper the Guardian has published several editorials explicitly stating the paper's stance against Brexit. The Telegraph, which is centre-right, has remained silent on the issue, but being one of the UK's most prominent right-wing voices, it is telling that they have not made their stance clear. The Independent is also explicitly against Brexit, as is the Mirror. The Sun has sort of come out for Brexit, ridiculing Cameron's negotiations on the front page recently, as has the Mail, and while this may sway some people, I don't think that there's enough unanimity on the issue for it to be decisive, and I think that what the Sun and Mail might be doing is using this to attack Cameron and his policies and negotiations, rather than actually voicing explicit support of Brexit. There's also been a lot of coverage on why Brexit would economically damn the UK. Recently, 36 FTSE 100 companies have signed a letter stating that the UK would be better of remaining. While no one really likes to listen the the corporate guys, this is undoubtedly going to have an impact on the vote: people are less likely to elect for change when it rocks the economic status quo. However, with that said, there has been growing right-wing, nationalist and anti-EU sentiment in the UK over the last few years, which has been reflected in unprecedented levels of membership for UKIP, and which can be seen in the Yougov polls which have been seesawing slightly (https://yougov.co.uk/news/2016/03/05/yougov-view-remain-ahead-support-fundamentals/). However, Yougov has also indicated that four polls in succession have seen Remain coming out on top, and while we might be quick to dismiss the accuracy of polling in light of the disastrous predictions of the general election of 2015, it should be noted that the issue of accuracy in that event stemmed from the "Blue Shame" phenomena of people not wanting to admit that they were conservatives. This series of polling will be less (although not completely not) politically sensitive for many people, and so it should be a pretty accurate reading of popular opinion.  Additionally, I think that the odds are politically stacked against Brexit: there are only three pro-Brexit parties  (the Democratic Unionist Party, Traditional Unionist Voice and UKIP; 8, 0 and 1 seats in the House of Commons respectively) and although they have a degree of popular support and following (DUP is the largest unionist party in Northern Ireland and UKIP had more votes than the SNP in the general election, and only lost out due to the first past the post system) they remain rather fringe parties on the grand scale of the UK political arena, with relatively small voices. This, of course, is not to say that anyone who voted for one of these parties will abide by the official position that they hold on any issue, but it is always useful to look at the political support that any issue holds because politicians do have the ability to bring their supporters to their side. In this case, the political support for Brexit seems to be very small. The SNP, who hold all but three of the seats in Scotland, oppose Brexit. So do the Labour party, who are uncharacteristically united on the matter. The only party with no official position on the matter is the Conservatives, and even then, the Prime Minister has voiced his desire for the UK to remain in the EU and the divide of opinion in the party is causing a mush publicised split. To top all of this off, I like to look at the bookies whenever there's a major political event underway to see what the professionals think. Currently, most bookmakers in the UK have the EU referendum scored like something to the effect of 1/3 to Stay and 9/4 to Leave, meaning that they overwhelmingly think that the UK is going to stay. Because of this, although I think that it will be a closer call than many expect, (possibly a 40-60 to 45-55 ), I think that the UK will vote to remain.

First Go: The Outside View (64% YES):
Based on the previous 11 referenda conducted in the UK (I've excluded the Belfast Agreement from the numbers because I think it's demonstrably different from all the rest), 7 out of 11 prior referenda have resulted in maintenance of the status quo (i.e. 64% vote for status quo). Although the Scottish Devolution referendum of '79 was actually a narrow vote FOR change, it just didn't qualify because the CHANGE vote was not greater than the 40% of pop. required.
If I include that as a CHANGE vote, I get 55% STATUS QUO votes. 
The problem with the UK is that there simply aren't enough referenda historically to create a large enough sample size for me to be confident that it is representative. 
If I look at Australia, there have been 44 referenda since 1906, 82% of which have been votes for the status quo. 
Given differences between Australia (and the nature of the referenda there) and the UK - I'm going to give the Australian sample a 1/3rd weight and the UK a 2/3rds weight. That gets me back to 64% STATUS QUO vote.  THE INSIDE VIEW
Generally, it appears to me that it is hard to get people to vote for CHANGE via referenda. It is even harder to get them to vote for change where there is a significant risk that CHANGE will make them worse off. 
On the basis that exiting the EU has clear negative risks (e.g. the GBP has already down from the mid 150's to high 130's vs the USD), I would bump the YES vote up substantially. 
A Feb 21-23 Yougov.com poll suggests that voters believe the REMAIN vote is the safer option by a 12 point lead. There is still a significant minority who believe it makes no difference, however. 
In an environment of no exogenous shocks, my inside view is that a REMAIN vote on June 23rd is about 90%. 
However... THE TERRORISM RISK
OUTSIDE VIEW:
One factor which could cause a dramatic shift in the vote would be if there was another terrorism attack or significant adverse event related to immigration, such as the Cologne sexual assaults by refugees, either in the UK or elsewhere in the EU. 
This could cause the "undecideds" and/or the "no difference [to my economic wellbeing]" crowd to swing to the NO camp.
So what is the chance of an ISLAMIC terrorist attack in the UK over the next 4 months? (I assume a terrorist attack from another group would not effect the outcome of the vote).
Statistically, it is miniscule (just over 1%). [I used Wikipedia history of terrorist attacks across Europe since 1958].
The chance of a non-specific terrorist attack somewhere in Europe is significantly higher:
I'm going to define a terrorist attack as a significant attack, killing more than 5 people. Since 1958 there have been 33, meaning a 57% chance in any year and a 19% chance in the next 4 months. 
Then I wondered whether there is any seasonality to the attacks - in total, there isn't. As you would expect, exactly 33.33% of all attacks have occurred in the months of March, April, May and June. 
However, if you look at the seasonality of larger than median attacks (killing + injuring greater than the median of 5 people) the Mar-June period is about 50% less likely to contain an attack in Europe than average would suggest.  So now I have the stats, what do I do with them? (INSIDE VIEW) Basically, I'm going to give them very little weight - why?
Let's assume there is a terrorist attack claimed by ISIL next week. 
If I were David Cameron, I would use that to swing the argument to portray the attack as an attempt to cause Brexit and make impassioned speeches in the vein of "Don't let the terrorists win". There is also some history of leaders gaining substantially in the polls post attacks... therefore, I'm going to assume this would actually help the REMAIN camp as voters swing behind Cameron and vote "against the terrorists". 
There is also the stat that 55% of voters think Brexit would make no difference to their safety, while only 16% think there is less risk, 10% think there is more risk and the balance are undecided. 
If I'm right, a terrorist attack in the UK would improve the odds of REMAINing in the EU, but the chance of it occurring are tiny. 
I'm not convinced that an attack on European soil would swing the vote either way, although I guess you might get some Solidarite` emotive REMAIN "I stand with Europe" vote swing if it happened.  PUTTING IT ALL TOGETHER:
I'm going to give the outside view a small weighting, given the significant economic unknowns created by a NO vote in this circumstance (20% weight). 
I'm going to give my inside view a huge weight of 80%, given the compelling reasons I can see not to vote NO and the potential YES vote sitting in the more granular polls (i.e. "which is the lower risk option").
CHANCE of YES vote = 84.8%
Business as usual until US election then revisit

The outcome of the referendum is difficult to call at this stage, particularly as there is a reasonably long horizon between now and the result.  Traditionally, referendums tend to favour the status quo. Whilst there are powerful voices calling for Brexit, the uncertainty of what would follow in its wake is perhaps the biggest factor at play, especially as the arguments both, for and against, are unclear to many. Even electoral experts are beset by a number of unknowns, hence the absence of decisive arguments on either side. Another factor to consider is that Scottish nationalists will favour the retention of the UK's EU status as many see it as an easier route to independence. The merit of this position is debatable in itself, but nonetheless it seems to be a factor. When we consider that the referendum itself was a sop to the reactionary supporters of UKIP (and their potential Tory backers), the relative decline of their message since the election suggests that anti-EU feeling is less fervent than it once was. If the EU avoids an economic collapse and the fears over immigration begin to dissipate, general apathy towards the EU may help sway voters towards the status quo as discussed above. Furthermore, an increasingly belligerent Russia, and China, together with the declining economic condition in the former, might make the case for strengthening our ties with our largest trading and security partners, not  weakening them. That's the basis of my initial assessment. I'll aim to add further analysis backed with data at a later date.

Brexit would be an economic catastrophe for Britain and could well be one for the rest of Europe as well. It's not like I'm saying something novel here[1][2][3].  But it can be difficult to disentangle the question "Is Brexit a bad idea for Britain?" from the question "Will Britain vote for Brexit?". I suppose I'd like to think that British voters will recognize their economic self-interest and the economic interests of the people with whom they currently share EU status. And I'd like to think that they will vote accordingly. But voters often put economic considerations in the background when making up their minds, as political scientists have known for a long time[4].  Perhaps the Brexit vote will play out in more-or-less the same way that the referendum on Scottish independence did. But before drawing a clear lesson from the 2014 vote, it's also worth remembering that (a) Scotland's population makes up only about 10% of Britain's, that (b) Scotland has been linked more deeply (in terms of gov't control) and for much longer to Britain than Britain has been to the EU, and that (c) the sorts of concerns that motivated (and still motivate) the desire for Scottish independence and not quite the same as those that motivate the desire for Brexit. For instance, partisans of Scottish independence did not seek, as far as I know, to combat the "likely...fall in relative importance [of Scotland] in the world"[5] as some Brexit backers do, mutatis mutandis. And certainly the anti-migrant rhetoric was not, to the best of my knowledge, a part of the argument for Scottish independence as it has been with Brexit[6]. Britain was my home for half a decade, and I don't won't to see her leave the EU, but that doesn't mean she won't. So for now I'm going to be keeping a close eye on the polls. -- [1] https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2016/03/03/everything-you-need-to-know-about-britain-leaving-the-european-union/?wpmm=1&wpisrc=nl_wonk

[4] http://www.jstor.org/stable/2110937

I doubt I have differentiated insight on this issue, but I think it's too close to call. My hypothesis is that EU membership is generally preferred by elites (a term I use descriptively, not as a value judgment) whose jobs directly or indirectly benefit from EU membership and/or who care about abstractions like standing in the international community. If this is true, the implication seems to me that it will be easier to marshal resources in favor of "yes" than "no." However, there is clearly a trend among non-elites in Western democracies to vote against what they perceive as elite priorities or candidates (e.g. Trump, Le Pen, etc.) regardless of the implications. I think this creates a practical difficulty for a "yes" campaign--the benefits of EU membership are diffuse and it is not obvious (to me) to what extent they accrue to non-elites, so how will this be sold? External shocks, if they happen, seem much more likely to shift opinion to "no"--terrorist attacks, further migration crises, and the like seem more likely to trigger a preference for isolation. I don't have a quantitative argument here, so I would call it a coin toss with a slight upgrade for status quo bias.

This is my initial forecast, so I'm in search of a reasonable starting place. What is most interesting (for me) at the moment is that there's a fairly large gap between what the betting market suggests is the right prior and what the polls suggest is the right prior. The betting market tells us that there's a 74% chance that Britain will vote to stay in the EU, and a 26% that she will vote to leave it[1]. But the polls are a different story. One source reports a poll of polls that shows that there is a 51% to 49% split for staying[2]. However, another sources report a different picture: "Nearly two thirds of UK voters are sceptical about the European Union, but less than a third want to leave, according to new analysis"[3]. The same course looks at the development of attitudes over time suggests that support for remaining in the EU has been growing over the last few years and is now roughly as high as it was in 1997. Betfair itself takes up the matter of the discrepancy between the market and the polls. Not surprisingly, it sides with the markets! But the discussion is worth reading and implies (if I understand it correctly) that, when Scottish independence was up for a vote in 2014, the polls initially suggested a fair amount of support for independence, but much of that support melted away as the date of the referendum drew nigh: "The build-up to the Scottish Independence referendum of 2014 was fairly low key for almost two years. It was only after the SNP had gained considerable momentum, and independence became a possibility, that the campaign sparked into life and the majority of Scots (and politicians from south of the border) engaged with the question. Ultimately, voters decided to stick with what they knew and keep Scotland in the union. When uncertainty kicks in closer to June 23, the likelihood is that the millions of undecided Brits, who don't feel strongly about the EU either way, will choose to support Remain"[4]. But I'm not sure that's how I read the data. Opposition to independence went from 61% in December 2013 to 55% in April 2014 to 51% in September 2014. So there wasn't really a trend in the polling away from being favorable to independence. Rather, what's relevant here is that the independence referendum was eventually defeated about 55% to 45%[5]. So - if the 2014 referendum is relevant here - the take away is not so much that we should expect the polls to narrow as we approach the Brexit vote. It's that we should expect the polls to indicate that there's more support for Brexit than the election will reflect.  And that might simply be because polling in Britain has not that predictive over the last decade or so[6][7]. (I hope I'm not being unfair to Betfair; maybe I just misread their point.) At this point, I think it's reasonable to afford the polls a 40% share of determining my prior and the betting market the rest, though I'll be hunting for better predictive measures. Stay in the EU = (0.4)(0.51) + (0.6)(0.74) = 0.648
Leave the EU = (0.4)(0.49) + (0.6)(0.26) = 0.352 -- [1] https://www.betfair.com/exchange/plus/#/politics/market/1.118739911 [2] http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/eureferendum/11617702/poll.html - probably taken from http://whatukthinks.org/eu/opinion-polls/poll-of-polls/# [3] http://www.theweek.co.uk/eu-referendum/65461/eu-referendum-poll-shows-drop-in-support-for-brexit [4] https://betting.betfair.com/politics/uk-politics/brexit-betting-update-eu-referendum-whos-right---the-polls-or-the-markets-030316-204.html [5] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_Scottish_independence_referendum,_2014 [6] http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/election_2010/8667801.stm [7] http://www.theguardian.com/politics/datablog/2015/mar/30/election-2015-can-we-trust-polling

Phone polls are most accurate (http://www.comres.co.uk/eu-referendum-all-still-to-play-for-by-not-neck-and-neck/ TLDR: phone polls get more representative samples), and this is the most recent phone poll I could find: http://www.comres.co.uk/polls/daily-mail-political-poll-february-2016/ The poll from Feb 23 with n=1000 showed 51% Remain in EU, 39% Leave, 10% undecided. (Comres applies its own correction for demographic and likely voter turnout, yielding 55% Remain, 37% Leave, 8% undecided.) This is closing the gap from their prior phone poll in Jan, which had 54% Remain, 36% Leave. From the most recent poll, assuming the 10% undecided splits 50/50 (though proportional distribution is more likely), that would mean 56% Remain, 44% Leave. With a MOE of +/-3, that puts Remain with over 99% confidence of being over 50%. While the trend towards a closer race is worth monitoring and many variables are left to be resolved, for the time being, I think the consensus is pretty low, which basically says there's only 1 SD between Remain and Leave. I'll be "conservative" and leave my current prediction at 95%, or 2 SDs. Reasons I'll change my forecast: online polling is more accurate (or phones less accurate) than I'm giving it credit for. Other telephone polls differing significantly from the Comres poll. New polls.

Opinion polls are in favor of Britain staying in the EU (Remain 53%, Leave 47%: http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/eureferendum/11617702/poll.html). Meanwhile, gambling site Betfair shows that odds-implied probability of Brexit has steadily increased from 20% in March 2015 to 36% presently (http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-10-28/brexit-odds-double-to-36-percent-at-bookmaker). It's unsurprising that the odds of Brexit have increased as campaign for the proposal has kicked into high gear. This article most succinctly evaluates the pros and cons of Brexit. The pros can be summarized as "the same..." while this author's three main points in favor of Brexit are:
1. On past form, the EU will continue to stretch its tentacles wider and deeper into every nook and cranny of national life. Hence, the costs of its interference will rise substantially. Meanwhile, over time the EU budget will surely increase. After all, the logic of moving towards a closer union is that the central budget should outrank national ones.
2. If most of the rest of the EU moves towards full fiscal and political union to make the euro work, it is going to be very uncomfortable for the UK to be inside the EU but outside that bloc. Whatever difficulties we have had over recent years in making our voice heard in Brussels are bound to get worse.
3. The EU is likely to fall in relative importance in the world. Admittedly, the UK doesn’t have to choose between trading with the EU and trading with the rest of the world. But if the rest of the world is continuing to grow in relative importance, then the benefits of EU membership would be proportionately smaller, and the costs yet more unnecessary. These are interesting from an academic perspective but essentially represent a nationalism argument and I don't think the EU is threatening the UK's sovereignty in any meaningful way to gather a lot of support for it. I will obviously follow this but my starting prediction reflects low probability for Brexit.

Embarrassingly, I misread the question the first time I made a prediction. I meant to predict a 40% chance of an EXIT vote! Original reasoning still stands: with polls essentially showing a 50/50 split between those who have decided, and a number of the undecideds being likely to feel compelled to vote, taking into account the evidence for that undecideds tend to favour the status quo on election days, the base case has to be for the UK to remain; however, it is a close call, and, if economic data (which has tended to correlate strongly with polls favouring leaving the EU) worsens for Europe, which you could easily imagine, given its heavy exports and slowing gllobal growth, we could definitely see an exit.

The base rate is about 50%, based on the YouGov survey. The strongest effect in favour of remaining in the EU is that it is the established situation, with less uncertainty about benefits and risks attached. Ups the base rate to about 65-70%. The strongest effect against remaining in the EU is the recency effect for refugee migration. But this effect only works on voters disposed against refugee admission, which is probably a proper subset of all voters. So this effect is smaller than the establishment effect, leading to 55-65%. Taking the mean of this range.

Now that the Mayor of London has come out for Brexit, there is a fairly good chance that it could happen. However, the fact that Britain could be swamped with refugees combined with the fact that Scotland wants to stay in the EU could mean the vote will be very close.
I think the Mayor of London while he has influence won't have majority influence in London, and the rest of the UK citizens outside of London stand to benefit more by remaining in the EU.
Concern for risks to the economy will triumph over concerns about immigration.

Don't believe UK will rock the status quo with Brexit. 50% trade with EU, despite downward trend, still #1 partner; other top trade partners USA, China have both expressed their preference of a UK with EU status based on various economic and strategic interests.  However unlikely the impact on Scotland may be, there is also at least a public perception that a Brexit would further complicate the discussion of Scottish Independence, which just adds more instability to the mix.  Cameron following through on offering the referendum can function in multiple capacities beyond just keeping his word among a domestic UK audience and among its partners abroad. Considering the potential negative economic impact of simply offering the referendum (e.g. some banks attribute Sterling devaluation to the referendum), in as much as it may be flirting with disaster, it should give the UK a glimpse into the future of the warm-/cold- reality of non-membership in EU.  Considering Cameron's original EU terms renegotiation and that his political longevity is directly tied to staying in the EU, plus his strategic concession to allow his own party members to decide on Brexit Yes/No independently offers him an  political dip-stick test into who in and outside of his party is interested in seeing him stick around. From now until the referendum the UK also has time to see if any of those interesting ‘opposite of the expected effect’ theories start to pan out; for example the argument from those who want to remain in the EU, that the Brexit makes bad economic sense just look at XYZ indicators has one anti-matter particle counterpart in the Barclay’s theory that the departure of a major economic power from the EU, such as the UK, might destabilize the EU, thus making the UK a haven for increased foreign direct investment. http://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2016/02/11/brexit-vote-could-turn-uk-into-a-safe-haven-triggering-eu-disint/ . An uptick in FDI, or at the very least, expressions of interest leading up to the referendum, seems measurable/testable and there should be some indicators beyond just official figures to watch on this. The referendum also may function to flatter UK domestic audience sensibilities about its own special status in the EU--it's a costly gamble, and seems like playing with fire.   Will follow the money on this one and keep a close eye on UK economic indicators leading up to the referendum as crucial determinant to this forecast: GDP, trade figures, changes in financial forecasts/ratings, etc. the gloomier the market stats trend leading up to the referendum, and the potential lack of those ‘opposite effect’ theories to provide extremely extremely compelling arguments about the Brexit’s long-term benefits will likely ensure the status quo and keep UK in the EU. The remain in the EU camp has it much easier, they have more actual historical data to draw from and only need to project a shadow of a doubt into the future to sway perceptions; the Brexit argument is much harder to make--will be watching for any extremely compelling arguments and equally compelling proof that they are part of the campaign circuit (i.e. out there), that there is grass-roots uptake of these ideas, and actions matched to exploit these opportunites--it's a tall order. Don't find this compelling basically because it's a poll, and because of the very same reasons they attribute Brexit as having an edge: "Analysis of the survey by Sir Lynton Crosby shows that voters who want Britain to leave the European Union are more motivated than those who say they are in favour of staying in."  Although the issue merits continued daily monitoring, (and inspiring people to stay tuned may be the media agenda behind this report), this article doesn't present compelling prove of a shifting tide. Honestly, either for or against party could be behind the agenda of this poll--it seems mostly about stirring the pot, waking people up. Will continue to watch.   The inherent problem with political polling seems to stem from--to posit an arm-chair theory--the mass tension generated by the collective asses of arm-chair political participants (not referring to participation in other aspects of life) worldwide, and the kinetic energy required for desperate politicians (whose daily-work is far removed from those asses and being mostly conducted indoors makes them too out-of-touch and out-of-shape to either kick ass or take names) to find people, to talk to, to get them to care, and then do something, while simultaneously thinking real interactions with people are too time-consuming. Instead of conducting ongoing interviews with a sample of individuals over time to appreciate things like life context to give some perspective on their consciously stated responses to questions, they want a short-term "now" index, or 'dip-stick' of where things stand, like cliff-notes for real interaction and understanding; in their busy-ness polls become an as needed all-in-one communications activity for cut-through, interaction, convincing, and motivation--but the entire interaction is short, low-quality, agenda-driven.  There is a significant amount of existing research/articles on polling and political manipulation; here are a few links:

This is an extremely difficult question. Forecasters have so far based their predictions of Britain remaining on two factors: economics and fear of the unknown. I have read every comment made so far, and I don't think I've seen one commenter whose reasoning I consider invalid. The prospect of Britain taking a severe economic hit and the frightening step into an uncertain future are real problems. The question is, how do people interpret these problems? When we talk about economic issues we tend to talk about macroeconomic issues. But from what I know, there's a lot of concern among native-born Britons over the "Polish plumber" problem; that is, unrestricted immigration from low-wage countries. This is an economic issue too; the concerns of the City of London may not figure prominently in the decisions of the electorate. This is not to say that macroeconomic matters don't affect people. Obviously these matters do. But if a voter is worried about unrestricted immigration endangering his wages or his employment, an appeal to macroeconomics won't work. And in fact, the voter may deliberately vote against the concerns of the City of London to spite people he feels have ignored him or undermined his own economic position.  As for the fearing the unknown, the long-term effect of immigration from continental Europe and the massive influx of asylum seekers is also unknown. There is the macroeconomic unknown, and the ethnic/nationalist unknown. The question is, which concern will govern people's votes? I think there is a good chance that voters will take the chance of economic turmoil in order to assert themselves as Britons. To repeat: from what I understand, many Britons already see themselves as enduring economic hardship. They will have to be sold on the idea that Brexit will make things worse, and I'm not sure that politicians and financiers who are already blamed for existing problems will be able to make a case that voters find convincing.
The economic benefits to the UK are greater when remaining in the EU, especially if they can maintain control over their own currency and not have to bail out the PIGS.

Maintaining status quo however unpalatable vs venturing out into what the electorate might consider virtual unknown political territory is how I break down the process at the start. Brits are a traditionally generous, giving group compared to their European neighbors. I think of the French as, my way or the highway types in culture & language terms. This, for want of a better description, bias which is almost systematic to reach out, be fair, wait in line &, just generally be British is what carries the top down analysis for me, in the first instance. Drilling down, I think most Brits @ this stage aren't in great economic condition so, wagering on a stand up & show our spirit vote to leave goes against this fundamental above-mentioned grain/tradition to seek a common ground. Add to this, Big biz in London &, the scaremongering of stormy waters for the next 5-10 years, if we vote Leave, add up at this point in my book to at least 55%. There is still time, I'll adjust accordingly w/ more/proper detail. But, for a start, I wanted to make this point before providing an updated number as things progress.
Long way to go until June

A vote to leave would damage the economy, certainly in the short term and probably in the long run. (As financial markets woke up to the prospect, the pound this week fell to its lowest level against the dollar since 2009.) It would imperil Britain’s security, when threats from terrorists and foreign powers are at their most severe in years. 
 the EU would have a strong incentive to impose a harsh settlement to discourage other countries from leaving. The Brexit camp’s claim that Europe needs Britain more than the other way round is fanciful: the EU takes almost half Britain’s exports, whereas Britain takes less than 10% of the EU’s; and the British trade deficit is mostly with the Germans and Spanish, not with the other 25 countries that would have to agree on a new trade deal.
 Britain outside the EU would be on the sidelines: notionally independent from, but in fact still constrained by, rules it would have no role in formulating. It would be a purer but rather powerless sort of sovereignty.
http://www.economist.com/news/leaders/21693584-leaving-eu-would-hurt-britainand-would-also-deal-terrible-blow-west-real-danger There are many more reasons for a NO-Brexit.
